gold_answer: The passages describe two complementary PRA permissions that can be used together when the PRA is addressing risks to its objectives. First, where it appears desirable to advance any of the PRA’s objectives, the PRA may impose a requirement on a firm under Part 4A to undertake or cease a particular action, and this is framed as an early-intervention tool where cultural failings could pose a risk to those objectives; importantly, the power may be used on a stand-alone basis rather than being tied to varying a firm’s permissions [#TGT:d7a983b39211c177]. Second, the PRA may also require a firm to provide specified information or information of a specified description, with further detail referenced in a Statement of policy on the financial stability information power [#SRC:31c588e91e693c8a]. Read together, the PRA can both direct conduct (do/stop an action) and compel targeted information from the firm, allowing it to identify, assess, and respond to potential cultural failings in a way that supports the advancement of the PRA’s objectives while using the action requirement independently of permission variation.

question: If the PRA thinks it needs to act early because a firm’s culture problems could threaten the PRA’s objectives, what can the PRA do to make the firm stop or start a specific action, and can it also make the firm give the PRA specific information?
gold_answer: Both passages explain that the PRA has tools it can use in parallel when it believes early intervention is needed to protect its objectives. On the action side, the PRA has the power to impose a requirement on a firm under Part 4A to undertake or cease a particular action, and one stated ground is where it appears desirable to do so in order to advance any of the PRA’s objectives; this is presented as enabling early intervention where cultural failings could pose a risk to those objectives, and the power can be used on a stand-alone basis rather than being linked to varying the firm’s permissions [#TGT:d7a983b39211c177]. Separately, the PRA may also require a firm to provide specified information or information of a specified description, with further details pointed to in the Statement of policy on the financial stability information power [#SRC:31c588e91e693c8a]. Together, this means the PRA can both direct what the firm must do (or stop doing) and require the firm to supply defined information to the PRA.

question: If the rule is said to apply to managing agents, what does a firm have to do about its audit committee in that situation?
gold_answer: Because the scope wording states that the provision is “as applied to managing agents” [#SRC:5f37b6287f9b3b61], you should read the audit committee requirement as operating in that managing agent setting. In that context, the firm has a direct duty: it must ensure that its audit committee performs at least the minimum functions that the requirement calls for [#TGT:0263bb5374885c09]. This is not just about having an audit committee on paper; the firm is responsible for making sure the committee actually carries out the required baseline functions. The scope reference to managing agents matters because it tells you when and where to apply the obligation—i.e., when dealing with managing agents—so the firm should not assume the obligation is limited to other contexts. Instead, the firm should treat the managing agent application as the relevant boundary for compliance and then meet the obligation by ensuring audit committee performance to at least the required minimum standard [#TGT:0263bb5374885c09], as framed by the managing agent scope [#SRC:5f37b6287f9b3b61].

question: When calculating the amount by which the firm must increase its exposure to assets determined under the specified methodology to reflect any exposure of the firm’s dependants, how must the firm limit that adjustment so it applies only in relation to the dependant’s surplus assets (or proportional share)?
gold_answer: In applying the requirement to increase the amount of the firm’s exposure to assets determined in accordance with the specified methodology, the firm must treat the increase as conditional and bounded by the scope limitation that the relevant provision applies only in relation to the dependant’s surplus assets (or proportional share) [#SRC:77b76f826536dc74]. Practically, this means the firm first identifies the assets “of that description” whose exposure has been determined under the referenced methodology, and then assesses whether there is any exposure of the firm’s dependants to those assets that would need to be reflected in the firm’s own exposure amount [#TGT:250709f3ef53e2f6]. However, the firm must not treat the dependant-related adjustment as applying to all dependant assets generally; it is confined to the dependant’s surplus assets (or proportional share), so only that surplus (or proportional share) is within the scope of the increase [#SRC:77b76f826536dc74]. The firm therefore increases its exposure amount only by an amount representing the dependants’ exposure, if any, to the relevant assets, and only to the extent that exposure relates to the dependant’s surplus assets (or proportional share) [#TGT:250709f3ef53e2f6].

question: For undertakings referred to in 11.1A(6), other than undertakings covered by point (5), how must the equity risk sub-module be structured when determining the relevant amount under the specified valuation and standard formula provisions?
gold_answer: For undertakings referred to in 11.1A(6), the scope condition is that the requirement applies only to those undertakings that are not covered by point (5) and that are determining an amount in accordance with the specified valuation and standard formula provisions [#SRC:a19de5e5078439a5]. Within that scoped determination, the equity risk sub-module must be constructed with distinct component risk sub-modules, so that the equity risk analysis is not treated as a single undifferentiated block. Specifically, the equity risk sub-module must include separate risk sub-modules for type 1 equities and type 2 equities, and it must also include dedicated risk sub-modules for qualifying infrastructure equities and for qualifying infrastructure corporate equities [#TGT:8a3ef0d20b9b4dac]. Read together, this means that an in-scope undertaking cannot omit any of these four equity categories when building the equity risk sub-module for purposes of the amount it determines under the referenced valuation and standard formula framework, and the undertaking must ensure the equity risk sub-module is segmented along those four required lines.

question: If an undertaking is one of those referred to in 11.1A(6) and is not in the group covered by point (5), what equity risk parts must it include when it works out the amount under the listed valuation and standard formula rules?
gold_answer: Where an undertaking falls within the stated scope—i.e., it is an undertaking referred to in 11.1A(6) and it is not an undertaking covered by point (5)—it must determine the relevant amount using the valuation and standard formula provisions identified in the scope text [#SRC:a19de5e5078439a5]. When doing so, the equity risk sub-module it uses cannot be left generic or incomplete: it must be built from specific required components. In particular, the equity risk sub-module must include a risk sub-module for type 1 equities and a risk sub-module for type 2 equities, and it must also include a risk sub-module for qualifying infrastructure equities and a risk sub-module for qualifying infrastructure corporate equities [#TGT:8a3ef0d20b9b4dac]. Putting the scope and obligation together, an in-scope undertaking must ensure that all four of these equity categories are explicitly represented as separate sub-modules within the equity risk sub-module when calculating the amount under the referenced valuation and standard formula framework.

question: How should firms operationalise the expectation to perform and refresh liquidity analysis promptly at the level of material entities, including making outputs available within the required turnaround, when the relevant supervisory reference point is the Bank’s SoP on FiR?
gold_answer: Firms are expected to be able to perform liquidity analysis on a timely basis at the level of material entities and to identify where liquidity risk may sit within those entities, and they should be able to refresh that analysis as necessary and deliver it promptly [#SRC:18166e48793fb892]. In aligning this capability with the supervisory reference point, firms should treat the Bank’s SoP on FiR as the contextual framework and ensure their approach is consistent with Paragraph 4.6 of that SoP [#TGT:6a4f41448caac1c1]. Operationally, this means having a robust mechanism to collect and compile the underlying information, and ensuring it is compliant with the firm’s relevant data quality processes, so that refreshed analysis can be produced and distributed without delay [#SRC:18166e48793fb892]. The output should be available on a T+1 basis, or faster where both necessary and appropriate, and the analysis should be adaptable so it can be readily adjusted to reflect stress circumstances, while still being produced at the material-entity level [#SRC:18166e48793fb892].

question: What do firms need to have in place to run liquidity analysis quickly for material entities and share it fast enough, and how does this tie back to the Bank’s SoP on FiR?
gold_answer: Firms should be able to carry out liquidity analysis quickly at the level of material entities, spot where liquidity risk could arise within those entities, and refresh the analysis when needed so they can deliver the information in a timely way [#SRC:18166e48793fb892]. This expectation should be implemented in a way that is consistent with the Bank’s SoP on FiR, specifically Paragraph 4.6, which is the cited reference point for the related requirement [#TGT:6a4f41448caac1c1]. Practically, firms need a robust process for collecting and compiling the inputs to the analysis, and that process must comply with the firm’s relevant data quality processes so the results are reliable and can be produced repeatedly under time pressure [#SRC:18166e48793fb892]. The analysis should be made available on a T+1 basis, or more rapidly if both necessary and appropriate, and it should be adaptable enough to be readily adjusted to reflect stress circumstances while still being produced at the material-entity level [#SRC:18166e48793fb892].

question: Where a firm enters into a material non-outsourcing third party arrangement, what must it do to ensure the PRA receives notice in line with the PRA’s expectation that such arrangements be brought to its attention, and how does this align with the firm’s duty to disclose matters the PRA would reasonably expect to be told?
gold_answer: A firm must treat material non-outsourcing third party arrangements as potentially falling within the category of matters the PRA would reasonably expect notice of, and therefore must bring those arrangements to the PRA’s attention in a manner and timeframe comparable to the approach described for notifying material outsourcing arrangements. This expectation arises because, even though the specific notification requirement referenced applies only to material outsourcing arrangements, material non-outsourcing third party arrangements may still constitute information the PRA would reasonably expect notice of. In parallel, the firm must deal with its regulators openly and cooperatively and must disclose to the PRA appropriately anything relating to the firm of which the PRA would reasonably expect notice, which captures these arrangements when they meet that threshold. Operationally, the firm may choose to implement a single internal framework that covers notifications to the PRA for both material outsourcing and material non-outsourcing third party arrangements, supporting consistent identification, escalation, and timely communication. These steps collectively ensure the firm both meets the PRA’s stated expectation to raise such arrangements proactively [#SRC:21e484c7d6d55c97] and satisfies its overarching obligation to disclose expected-notice information appropriately [#TGT:ab86212dc24973dd].

question: If a fee is a “special project fee” (as specified in the relevant provision), when does the firm have to pay an SPF for restructuring after the PRA sends an invoice?
gold_answer: If the fee you are dealing with falls within the defined category of “special project fees,” which the source text ties to what is “as specified” in the referenced provision [#SRC:ad40c03e3a8c8ea1], then the payment timing for an “SPF for restructuring” is set by the target obligation. The firm must pay an SPF for restructuring by the due date that is calculated as 30 days from the date shown on each invoice that the PRA issues to the firm [#TGT:bcf7e19d119fd6d9]. In practical terms, you first confirm that the charge is being treated as a special project fee under the specified framework [#SRC:ad40c03e3a8c8ea1]. Then, for each invoice received from the PRA that relates to restructuring, you count 30 days starting from the invoice date to determine the payment deadline [#TGT:bcf7e19d119fd6d9]. Because the rule is tied to “each invoice,” the 30-day clock runs separately for every invoice the PRA sends for restructuring-related SPF amounts.

question: When a PRA-regulated firm is about to start, or make a big change to, an outsourcing arrangement, what counts as “material outsourcing” (especially for services covered by OCIR), and when does the firm need to notify the PRA if the arrangement will become material later?
gold_answer: A PRA-regulated firm must notify the PRA when it is entering into, or significantly changing, a material outsourcing arrangement, and the PRA expects the firm to send that notification before entering into the outsourcing arrangement [#SRC:4feca3a835842f71]. To decide whether the arrangement is “material outsourcing,” the firm should treat outsourcing of services to which OCIR applies as generally material outsourcing [#TGT:460ccc4d06705d20]. The definition is broader than OCIR alone: even if an arrangement is not within scope of OCIR, it might still be material outsourcing where it could affect the PRA’s objectives outside an OCIR context, including arrangements involving personal or sensitive data or those carrying high reputational risk [#TGT:460ccc4d06705d20]. If the firm did not initially consider an outsourcing arrangement to be material, the PRA still expects the firm to notify before the arrangement is expected or planned to become material [#SRC:4feca3a835842f71]. The PRA will consider how timely the firm’s notification is when assessing the firm’s compliance with Fundamental Rule 7 [#SRC:4feca3a835842f71].

question: If you are using the older Annex 1 information sheet (Chapter 16) from before 01/12/2025, what should it tell customers about FSCS deposit protection, how they can check if their deposits with [name of firm] are covered, and where to find any exclusions?
gold_answer: If the firm is using the past version of Annex 1 – Information Sheet (Chapter 16) from before 01/12/2025, the information sheet should still give customers a clear, practical explanation of how deposit protection works and where to look for key details [#SRC:6c8ef187e7b75e4a]. It should explain that the Financial Services Compensation Scheme (‘FSCS’) protects deposits made by most individuals and businesses, so customers understand the general scope of protection [#TGT:f949291233620ea1]. It should also tell customers exactly how to check whether their own deposits with [name of firm] are eligible for FSCS protection: their account statement is the place that will confirm eligibility [#TGT:f949291233620ea1]. Finally, it should warn customers that there are some exclusions from FSCS protection and point them to where those exclusions are listed—specifically, the exclusions list that appears after the information sheet [#TGT:f949291233620ea1]. Putting these points together ensures the older information sheet version remains usable and directs customers to both confirmation and limitations [#SRC:6c8ef187e7b75e4a] [#TGT:f949291233620ea1].

question: When documenting the purpose and use of a model in the model inventory, how must the Authorised Person treat and describe the model’s operating boundaries, and what does that term mean for assessing whether the model is being used as intended versus how it is actually used?
gold_answer: In capturing the purpose and use of a model, the model inventory must include not only the relevant product or portfolio and the intended use compared to the model’s actual use, but also the model operating boundaries under which model performance is expected to be acceptable [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd]. The term “Operating boundaries” must be understood and applied as defined: it is the sample data range used to estimate the parameters of a statistical model, including empirical variance-covariance relationships in the multivariate case [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b]. Practically, this means the Authorised Person should record operating boundaries as a concrete, data-based range that frames where performance expectations are valid, and then use that framing to evaluate whether actual use remains consistent with the intended use and acceptable performance conditions. Because extrapolating beyond a model’s operating boundaries (for example, using macroeconomic indices in shock or stressed economic conditions) should be assumed to involve increased model risk, the inventory’s purpose-and-use description should flag when actual use extends beyond the sample data range and therefore carries heightened risk relative to the intended use [#TGT:67bcc3ea827b033b] while still meeting the inventory capture expectations [#SRC:7e96d775d78d33bd].

question: What must an undertaking do to make sure its assumptions about future management actions are realistic, and how should it deal with the relevant deviations from those assumptions that are referenced in the technical provisions?
gold_answer: An undertaking must start by ensuring that its assumptions about future management actions are realistic, meaning they are set on a credible and supportable basis rather than being aspirational or unsupported [#TGT:21a461da99c417d7]. At the same time, it must pay attention to the relevant deviations from those assumptions that are referenced in the technical provisions, and treat those deviations as items that need to be identified and addressed rather than ignored [#SRC:10677cafcf3c727c]. In practice, the undertaking should clearly state the assumptions it is using for future management actions so they can be evaluated for realism, and then separately list the deviations that are considered relevant under the referenced technical provisions. It should explain how those deviations relate back to the assumptions: whether they show that an assumption needs to be adjusted to remain realistic, or whether they represent a relevant departure that should be tracked and explained even if the core assumption remains realistic. This ensures the undertaking meets the realism requirement while also properly capturing the referenced deviations.

question: If an insurer wants to know whether the PRA’s expectations apply to it, what does “significant” mean here, and how does that link to the PRA’s view about smaller insurers versus larger firms with complex risk profiles?
gold_answer: In this context, the PRA is drawing a boundary around who the expectations are meant to apply to. The PRA explains that it believes smaller insurers—most of which operate in one locality or a niche market—would face a disproportionate cost impact if they tried to meet the expectations in the supervisory statement, so the PRA limits the application of those expectations to significant firms only, while stating that larger firms with complex risk profiles should seek to meet (or exceed) the expectations when complying with regulatory requirements [#SRC:15dcfe5ca573a1b6]. To understand what “significant” means for that boundary, the definition provided is that Category 1 and Category 2 firms are deemed significant within the PRA’s supervisory framework model, as described in the PRA’s approach to insurance supervision [#TGT:86a53c4da46b88c3]. Putting the two together: if the insurer is Category 1 or 2 under the supervisory framework, it is treated as significant and the expectations are intended to apply to it; if it is not Category 1 or 2, the PRA’s stated rationale indicates the expectations are not intended to be applied to it because of the disproportionate cost concern for smaller insurers.

question: A firm has to show one calculated amount as a percentage of another. Before doing that, what must the firm subtract from the base amount because of reinsurance contracts ceded during the relevant period?
gold_answer: Before a firm expresses the later-step amount as a percentage of the earlier-step amount, it must treat the earlier-step amount as reduced by a specific deduction tied to reinsurance. The firm must deduct, from the amount determined under the earlier step, the total sum recoverable in respect of that amount under reinsurance contracts ceded during the relevant period [#TGT:132742aa0c2fba72]. After making that deduction, the firm must then express the amount determined under the later step as a percentage of the (now deducted) amount determined under the earlier step, because the percentage expression requirement is explicitly framed by reference to the earlier-step amount [#SRC:237261b1461b9a23]. Practically, this means the “base” used for the percentage is not the undeducted earlier-step figure; it is the earlier-step figure after subtracting the total reinsurance recoverables that are recoverable in respect of that amount and that arise under reinsurance contracts ceded during the relevant period [#TGT:132742aa0c2fba72]. The firm must ensure the percentage presentation reflects this sequencing so the percentage is computed against the correctly adjusted base amount [#SRC:237261b1461b9a23].

question: For the disclosures that must be made about exposure to credit risk and dilution risk, what procedure must Institutions follow to ensure those disclosures are prepared in the required format, including any mandated template and instructions?
gold_answer: Institutions must make disclosures about their exposure to credit risk and dilution risk, and the procedural requirement for the specific set of disclosures referenced is that they be prepared using the prescribed reporting format and guidance. Concretely, where the disclosures are those required for the relevant point, Institutions must compile and present them in accordance with the Template UK CR2 set out in Annex XV, and they must also follow the relevant instructions set out in Annex XVI. This means the obligation to disclose information on exposure to credit risk and dilution risk is not satisfied merely by providing narrative or ad hoc figures; the disclosures must be produced through the defined template-driven process and aligned to the accompanying instruction set. In practice, Institutions should treat the template and instructions as the controlling procedure for how the required information is structured and completed, so that the disclosure content is delivered in the expected layout and with the expected interpretation of fields and terms, consistent with the referenced annexes. [#TGT:e7ba9eb1cd7f5dc8] [#SRC:792f116bdfb20a14]

question: When Institutions have to disclose information about credit risk and dilution risk exposure, what template and instructions must they use for the specific disclosures tied to that requirement?
gold_answer: Institutions have a duty to disclose information about their exposure to credit risk and dilution risk. For the particular disclosures that are identified as being required under the referenced point, the way Institutions must prepare those disclosures is specified: they must be produced in accordance with Template UK CR2 in Annex XV, and Institutions must apply the relevant instructions set out in Annex XVI. This links the disclosure obligation to a concrete preparation method, so Institutions are not free to choose any format; instead, they must use the named template and follow the associated instruction set when compiling the required information. As a result, compliance involves both (i) ensuring the disclosure covers the required subject matter—exposure to credit risk and dilution risk—and (ii) ensuring the disclosure is completed using the mandated template structure and the relevant instructions, so the information is presented consistently with the annexed requirements. [#TGT:e7ba9eb1cd7f5dc8] [#SRC:792f116bdfb20a14]

question: If an intermediate holding company holds subordinated debt or other own funds that are capped by limits, how much of it must be counted as eligible own funds, and how does that link to the rule that, to comply with its SCR, at least some conditions must be met?
gold_answer: If an intermediate holding company holds subordinated debt or other eligible own funds that are subject to a limitation, the amount that can be counted is restricted: those items must be recognised as eligible own funds only up to the amounts calculated by applying the relevant limits to the total eligible own funds outstanding at the level of the group, measured against the group SCR [#SRC:7e7611b013e56b89]. This matters for SCR compliance because the TARGET states that, for compliance with its SCR, at least certain conditions must be met [#TGT:d1eb727f3749f8b3]. Putting the two together, the SCR compliance check cannot rely on the full face value of the limited subordinated debt or other limited own-funds items held by the intermediate holding company; it must use the capped amount produced by the limit calculation at group level and then apply that result within the SCR-compliance framework that requires meeting at least the stated conditions. In practice, the eligible own funds used in the SCR comparison must reflect the limit-based recognition outcome, because that is the required treatment for those holdings and is part of satisfying the SCR compliance conditions [#SRC:7e7611b013e56b89] [#TGT:d1eb727f3749f8b3].

question: For firms with RFB sub-groups, how must the firm ensure that the group recovery plan adequately reflects the RFB sub-group, and what is the relevant publication date and reference location for the supervisory expectations being applied?
gold_answer: Where a firm has RFB sub-groups, it is expected to apply the supervisory expectations associated with ring-fenced bodies and to translate those expectations into the firm’s recovery planning. In practice, the firm should ensure that the recovery plan for a group that includes an RFB adequately reflects the RFB sub-group, rather than treating recovery planning solely at a consolidated group level, because the expectations are stated to apply specifically to firms with RFB sub-groups and require the RFB sub-group to be properly captured in the plan [#SRC:5895c2edc411bfc8]. The relevant supervisory expectations are those referenced as being in the ring-fenced bodies supervisory statement, and the associated reference location is provided as a Bank of England Prudential Regulation publication link, with the publication date explicitly indicated as December 2017 [#TGT:0fef19d1ce547b63]. Accordingly, a firm should align its recovery plan content with those ring-fenced bodies expectations and be able to point to the December 2017 publication reference as the source location for the expectations it is applying [#SRC:5895c2edc411bfc8] [#TGT:0fef19d1ce547b63].

question: If a firm has an RFB sub-group, what should it do to make sure its group recovery plan covers the RFB sub-group properly, and where (and when) is the related ring-fenced bodies guidance published?
gold_answer: If a firm has an RFB sub-group, it should treat the ring-fenced bodies expectations as applicable to it and then make sure the recovery plan for any group that includes an RFB adequately reflects the RFB sub-group. That means the firm should not draft a recovery plan that only describes the group in general terms; instead, it should ensure the plan explicitly takes account of the RFB sub-group because the expectations are stated to apply to firms with RFB sub-groups and call for the RFB sub-group to be adequately reflected in the group recovery plan [#SRC:5895c2edc411bfc8]. The related ring-fenced bodies material is identified by a Bank of England Prudential Regulation publication reference, and the date given for that reference is December 2017, with a link to the publication location provided [#TGT:0fef19d1ce547b63]. So, the firm’s practical task is to align its recovery plan approach with those expectations and be able to cite the December 2017 publication location as the place where the expectations are set out [#SRC:5895c2edc411bfc8] [#TGT:0fef19d1ce547b63].

question: When a firm draws down buffers within the capital framework during a period of stress, how does the PRA’s stated permission to use those buffers interact with the PRA’s expectations for rebuilding them, and where is the related ICAAP/SREP material identified for further reference?
gold_answer: The PRA’s position is that firms may use all buffers in the capital framework, explicitly including the PRA buffer, when stress conditions require it, and the PRA indicates it will be content for firms to rebuild those buffers over a reasonable period rather than immediately [#SRC:cf55dc9054b4cdbf]. In determining what is “reasonable,” the PRA applies judgement that takes account of how much of the buffer has been used and how long the stress is expected to last, and it also considers firm-specific drivers for the buffer usage in the context of current and forecast macroeconomic and financial conditions [#SRC:cf55dc9054b4cdbf]. The PRA further clarifies that firms are not expected to hold extra capital solely to avoid being within the PRA buffer in a stress scenario, reinforcing that buffer usability is an intended feature of the framework rather than a breach to be pre-empted [#SRC:cf55dc9054b4cdbf]. For related supervisory context, the cross-referenced material identified is the Bank of England/PRA publication titled “The Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Process (ICAAP) and the Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process (SREP),” dated March 2019, which is provided as a linked reference [#TGT:a6f49674c529a776].

question: If a firm uses its capital buffers during stress, can it do that under the PRA’s approach, what does the PRA look at when deciding how quickly buffers should be rebuilt, and which ICAAP/SREP document is pointed to for more information?
gold_answer: Yes. The PRA states that all buffers in the capital framework, including the PRA buffer, can be used when needed in times of stress, and it indicates it will be content for firms to rebuild buffers that have been drawn down over a reasonable period of time [#SRC:cf55dc9054b4cdbf]. The PRA’s assessment of what counts as a reasonable rebuilding period is not fixed; it is based on its judgement and takes into account (i) the amount by which the buffer has been used and (ii) the expected duration of the stress [#SRC:cf55dc9054b4cdbf]. It also considers firm-specific reasons for the buffer use, and it does so in the context of current and forecast macroeconomic and financial conditions, which frames how the PRA interprets the firm’s situation during and after the stress event [#SRC:cf55dc9054b4cdbf]. The PRA also makes clear there is no expectation for firms to hold additional capital just to avoid being within the PRA buffer in a stress, consistent with buffers being usable [#SRC:cf55dc9054b4cdbf]. The referenced ICAAP/SREP document for further context is “The Internal Capital Adequacy Assessment Process (ICAAP) and the Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process (SREP),” March 2019, provided via a Bank of England link [#TGT:a6f49674c529a776].

question: If a bank is an international bank or a UK trading bank, what does it need to do about the risks from a global booking model in its resolution and wind-down planning, especially if an MPE strategy could apply?
gold_answer: Because the PRA’s expectations for booking arrangements apply to all international banks and UK trading banks, a bank in scope should ensure its approach to booking is aligned with those expectations, applied in a way that is proportionate to how much investment banking or sales and trading activity it undertakes [#SRC:8a9b8ceafce61236]. When the bank uses a global booking model, it should not assume the model is neutral for resolution planning: even where it may not be a direct impediment under a single point of entry resolution strategy, it can still add complexity to restructuring the group after resolution [#TGT:9fcb3c210c05859d]. More importantly, under a multiple-point-of-entry strategy, the inter-connectivity between the UK authorised firm and the group associated with global booking could itself be an impediment to resolution that the bank should address [#TGT:9fcb3c210c05859d]. The PRA also expects the bank’s contingency plans for winding down trading books in a solvent and orderly way to fully take into account the particular booking model the bank has adopted [#TGT:9fcb3c210c05859d].

question: When assessing whether a credit institution falls within the circumstances in which the PRA will determine that its arrangements, strategies, processes, and mechanisms (together with its own funds and liquidity) ensure sound risk management and coverage, how does the PRA’s stated approach for STS ABCP sponsor purposes limit the applicability of that determination, and what precondition relating to ABCP programmes must the firm satisfy?
gold_answer: The baseline position is that the PRA’s determination is made on the basis of its review and evaluation of whether the credit institution’s arrangements, strategies, processes, and mechanisms, together with the own funds and liquidity it holds, ensure the sound management and coverage of its risks [#SRC:b99fc6e0f4b4c219]. However, for the specific scope of being an STS ABCP sponsor, the PRA indicates it is unlikely to make that determination unless an additional applicability condition is met: the firm must currently be a sponsor for at least one ABCP programme [#TGT:1ed088c2d925583a]. This frames the determination as not merely a general assessment of governance, risk controls, and financial resources, but one that is constrained by the firm’s current sponsorship status in the ABCP market for STS ABCP sponsor purposes. The target text further clarifies that the relevant “at least one ABCP programme” can include an existing non-STS ABCP programme for which the firm wishes to seek STS status, meaning the precondition can be satisfied even where the programme is not yet STS, provided the firm is already acting as sponsor [#TGT:1ed088c2d925583a].

question: Where a firm uses cloud technology to distribute its data and applications across multiple, geographically dispersed availability zones and regions to improve operational resilience, what must the firm do for each material outsourcing arrangement in terms of developing, maintaining, and testing the required artefact expected by the PRA?
gold_answer: When a firm uses cloud technology to distribute its data and applications across multiple, geographically dispersed availability zones and regions, the PRA recognises that this can deliver operational resilience benefits, including faster and more effective response and recovery from local operational outages and improved ability to cope with fluctuations in demand [#SRC:215414e9498f9210]. However, those resilience objectives do not remove the PRA’s expectation that, for each material outsourcing arrangement, firms take specific governance and assurance steps: the firm is expected to develop, maintain, and test the required artefact for that arrangement [#TGT:20dec419321d50d1]. Practically, this means the firm should treat each material outsourcing arrangement as needing its own documented, kept-up-to-date, and exercised set of arrangements that can be relied upon if an outage occurs in a particular zone or region, or if demand spikes. The expectation applies on a per-arrangement basis, so distributing workloads across regions should be reflected in what is developed, how it is maintained over time, and how it is tested to demonstrate it supports the firm’s ability to respond and recover as intended [#SRC:215414e9498f9210] [#TGT:20dec419321d50d1].

question: If you are dealing with managing agents and a requirement mentions “SCR”, what does “SCR” mean in that context, and what must a firm do in its ongoing risk-management system to make sure risks are identified, measured, monitored, managed, and reported using that meaning?
gold_answer: In the context of requirements applied to managing agents, any reference to “SCR” must be interpreted as a reference to the notional syndicate SCR calculated by managing agents as required by Solvency Capital Requirement - General Provisions 8.2 [#SRC:44175f318dae3378]. Separately, a firm must have an effective risk-management system that it establishes, implements, and maintains, with strategies, processes, and reporting procedures that work continuously to identify, measure, monitor, manage, and report risks at both an individual and aggregated level, including how those risks depend on each other [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca]. Putting these together, when the firm’s risk-management system uses SCR-related information for managing agents—whether in measurement, monitoring, aggregation, or reporting—it must treat “SCR” as the notional syndicate SCR calculated by managing agents, and ensure the system’s continuous reporting and aggregation processes are aligned to that interpretation so that risk outputs and interdependency assessments are based on the correct SCR meaning.

question: When determining the amount of the long-term insurance liability for each contract by a prospective calculation, under what conditions may the firm use approximations or generalisations, and how must it ensure those simplifications do not understate the result compared with a full determination?
gold_answer: The firm must determine the amount of the long-term insurance liability for each contract using a prospective calculation, and it must do so on a contract-by-contract basis, subject to the stated constraints in the liability determination framework [#TGT:72c3af495575a5fb]. Within that required prospective calculation, the firm is permitted to use appropriate approximations or generalisations only in the limited circumstance where those simplifications are likely to produce the same result as, or a higher result than, the outcome that would be produced by making the determination in accordance with the referenced determination approach [#SRC:0d7554db3da9e2ab]. Practically, this means the obligation to calculate prospectively for each contract remains the baseline, and any use of approximations must be justified by an expectation that the approximation will not reduce the calculated liability relative to the more direct determination method. If the firm cannot reasonably conclude that the approximation or generalisation will meet that “same or higher” threshold, it should not be used within the prospective calculation, because the permission is expressly conditional and does not override the requirement to determine the liability amount for each contract as specified [#TGT:72c3af495575a5fb] [#SRC:0d7554db3da9e2ab].

question: You must calculate the long-term insurance liability for each contract using a forward-looking method. When are you allowed to use simplified approximations or generalisations, and what outcome must those simplifications be expected to produce compared with doing the full determination?
gold_answer: You are required to determine the amount of the long-term insurance liability for each contract using a prospective (forward-looking) calculation, meaning the calculation must be performed for each individual contract and follow the applicable framework for that prospective approach [#TGT:72c3af495575a5fb]. At the same time, you may use appropriate approximations or generalisations, but only on a restricted basis: the simplification is permitted solely where it is likely to give the same result as, or a higher result than, the result you would get if you performed the determination using the referenced determination method [#SRC:0d7554db3da9e2ab]. In other words, the simplification cannot be used just for convenience; it must be expected not to reduce the calculated liability compared with the more direct determination. If you cannot support the expectation that the approximation will match or increase the result relative to the full determination approach, then the condition for using approximations is not met, and you must rely on the prospective calculation without that simplification to satisfy the per-contract liability determination requirement [#TGT:72c3af495575a5fb] [#SRC:0d7554db3da9e2ab].

question: Where a firm uses the TMTP method and a transfer event changes the firm’s technical provisions to which the TMTP relates, what must the firm do, and by when, measured from the effective date of that transfer event? In answering, include the condition that limits when an update is permitted and the basis on which the update is expected to be calculated.
gold_answer: A firm that uses the TMTP method must update its TMTP methodology when a transfer event results in a change in the firm’s technical provisions to which the TMTP relates [#SRC:283cc6b77dc06a2b]. The timing requirement is that, within two months of the effective date of any transfer event, a firm must take the required action(s) triggered by that event, which includes making the TMTP methodology update where the source condition is met [#TGT:c7d27d491bf904f9]. The update is only permitted where the business that has been transferred or ceded was subject to TMTP prior to the transfer, so the firm should confirm that precondition before proceeding [#SRC:283cc6b77dc06a2b]. In addition, the PRA expects the update to be based on figures at the effective date of the transfer or transaction, so the firm should anchor the recalculation to that effective-date data while meeting the two-month deadline [#SRC:283cc6b77dc06a2b] [#TGT:c7d27d491bf904f9].

question: If a firm uses the TMTP method and a transfer event changes the technical provisions that the TMTP relates to, what does the firm have to do and what is the deadline from the transfer’s effective date? Also, when is the update allowed and what figures should it be based on?
gold_answer: If a firm uses the TMTP method and a transfer event results in a change in the firm’s technical provisions to which the TMTP relates, the firm is required to update its TMTP methodology [#SRC:283cc6b77dc06a2b]. The deadline is tied to the transfer’s effective date: within two months of the effective date of any transfer event, a firm must complete the required step(s) associated with that event, which includes making the TMTP methodology update when the trigger condition is met [#TGT:c7d27d491bf904f9]. The firm should also check the limitation on when it can do this: the update is only permitted if the business that has been transferred or ceded was subject to TMTP before the transfer, so the firm should not treat the update as available for business that was not previously within TMTP [#SRC:283cc6b77dc06a2b]. Finally, the PRA expects the update to be based on figures at the effective date of the transfer or transaction, so the firm should use effective-date figures as the basis for the update while meeting the two-month timing requirement [#SRC:283cc6b77dc06a2b] [#TGT:c7d27d491bf904f9].

question: When a firm calculates the SCR using an internal model, how must it ensure the resulting calibration delivers an equivalent level of policyholder protection, and how should that approach be aligned with the PRA Rulebook’s general provisions on the Solvency Capital Requirement?
gold_answer: A firm using an internal model to calculate the SCR should ensure that the model’s calibration delivers policyholder protection equivalent to a value-at-risk standard applied to the firm’s basic own funds, using a 99.5% confidence level over a one-year horizon [#SRC:3862b1cc447d1667]. In applying that calibration, the firm should also explicitly consider how basic own funds may change as a result of risk events, including changes driven by movements in the value of the assets and liabilities of a pension scheme, because those dynamics affect whether the internal model continues to provide the intended level of protection [#SRC:3862b1cc447d1667]. This internal-model calibration and the associated assessment of changes in basic own funds should be framed and evidenced in a manner consistent with the Solvency Capital Requirement general provisions referenced in the PRA Rulebook (General Provisions 3.3 and 3.4) [#TGT:d80c6debace3e8ea], so that the firm can demonstrate that its internal model approach to SCR remains aligned with the applicable SCR framework while meeting the stated protection objective.

question: If a firm uses an internal model to work out its SCR, what does it need to do to make sure policyholders are protected to the right level, and how does that connect to the PRA Rulebook’s general SCR provisions?
gold_answer: If a firm calculates the SCR using an internal model, it should set the model so that it gives policyholders a level of protection equivalent to a value-at-risk calibration applied to the firm’s basic own funds, using a 99.5% confidence level over a one-year period [#SRC:3862b1cc447d1667]. To support that outcome, the firm should think through how basic own funds could change when risk events happen, because those changes can affect whether the internal model still delivers the intended protection level; the passage highlights that part of the change may come from shifts in the value of the assets and liabilities of a pension scheme [#SRC:3862b1cc447d1667]. This work should be tied back to the Solvency Capital Requirement general provisions identified in the PRA Rulebook (General Provisions 3.3 and 3.4) [#TGT:d80c6debace3e8ea], so the firm can show that its internal-model SCR approach is being applied within the relevant SCR framework while meeting the protection objective.

question: For purposes of applying requirements that refer to “systemically important firms,” how should a firm determine whether it falls within that category, and which PRA publication should be used to understand the identification approach for the designation process?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the term “systemically important firms” as a defined reference to firms that are designated under the other systemically important institutions (O-SII) identification process, rather than as a standalone label based on a firm’s own assessment. In practice, this means the firm’s status turns on whether it has been designated through the O-SII identification process described for that purpose [#SRC:4e68bcd43c4b336d]. To understand the relevant identification approach and the context for how the designation process is framed, the firm should consult the PRA statement of policy titled “The PRA’s approach to identifying other systemically important institutions (O-SIIs)” (December 2020), which is the referenced publication for the O-SII identification approach [#TGT:ddf25f3a37eebea3]. Read together, the definition ties “systemically important firms” directly to designation under the O-SII identification process, and the cited PRA SoP is the document that sets out the PRA’s approach to identifying O-SIIs, which is the process through which such designation occurs.

question: If a policy says it applies to “systemically important firms,” what does that mean in plain terms, and where should you look to understand how the PRA identifies and designates those firms?
gold_answer: In plain terms, “systemically important firms” is not a general description you decide by judgment; it is a specific reference to firms that are designated under the other systemically important institutions (O-SII) identification process [#SRC:4e68bcd43c4b336d]. So, to decide whether the label applies, you should focus on whether the firm has been designated through that O-SII identification process, because the definition links the category directly to that designation outcome. To understand how the PRA approaches identifying O-SIIs (the process that leads to designation), you should look to the PRA statement of policy titled “The PRA’s approach to identifying other systemically important institutions (O-SIIs)” dated December 2020, which is the referenced document for that identification approach [#TGT:ddf25f3a37eebea3]. Using both pieces together: the definition tells you what the term means (designation under the O-SII identification process), and the PRA SoP is the place to understand the PRA’s approach to that identification process.

question: If a firm uses one of the options to meet the marking requirement, what does the PRA say the separate file must contain, and what does it say the file does not need to contain, given that the same earlier considerations still apply?
gold_answer: If firms wish to use one of the available options to meet the marking requirement, they should proceed on the basis that the same considerations that apply in the earlier marking discussion also apply to that option-based approach [#SRC:80fa2ccc96a66fd6]. Within that scope, the PRA defines the separate file generated under whichever option in a limited way: it only needs to contain a list of unique identification account numbers, and that list can include eligible and/or ineligible accounts as relevant to the firm’s marking process [#TGT:2af5e3a136acf878]. The PRA also makes clear that the separate file does not need to include customer information or balance information [#TGT:2af5e3a136acf878]. So, when applying the earlier considerations to an option-based method, a firm can keep the separate file focused on the account-number list and should not treat the option as requiring extra customer or balance details to be added to that file [#SRC:80fa2ccc96a66fd6] [#TGT:2af5e3a136acf878].

question: When does this Part apply to a group, and if it does, who in the group has to make sure there are enough eligible own funds to cover the group SCR?
gold_answer: This Part only applies “at the level of the group” and only for certain “types of groups,” so the first step is to determine whether the group you are assessing falls within the types covered by that scope statement [#TGT:68c8c37fed32deed]. If the group is within scope, then the requirement is not optional: each participating Solvency II undertaking that is a firm in the group and each relevant insurance group undertaking must ensure that eligible own funds are available in the group. The standard they must meet is continuous—eligible own funds must always be at least equal to the group SCR. The group SCR is the group solvency capital requirement amount as calculated under the referenced calculation provisions, and it is the benchmark against which the “always at least equal” test is applied [#SRC:17dc5c7d4f47f6cd]. So, applicability depends on the group-type scope, and once applicable, the named undertakings must maintain eligible own funds at or above the calculated group SCR.

question: A credit union is prohibited from holding investments unless an exception applies. Does the exception permit the credit union to hold a fixed-interest sterling-denominated security that is guaranteed by the UK government where the instrument’s maturity is no more than five years from the date the investment is made?
gold_answer: The starting position is that a credit union is prohibited from holding investments unless it falls within the stated carve-out that allows it to hold an investment meeting specified criteria [#TGT:d83625f1bbe08d65]. One such permitted category is a fixed-interest sterling-denominated security that is guaranteed by the UK government, but only where the maturity does not exceed five years measured from the date on which the investment is made [#SRC:19179ef3e061cca9]. Accordingly, the prohibition is not absolute: the credit union may hold an investment if (and only if) it fits within that defined description, including the maturity cap and the requirement that the security be both fixed-interest and sterling-denominated, with a UK government guarantee [#SRC:19179ef3e061cca9]. If the instrument’s maturity extends beyond five years from the investment date, or if it is not sterling-denominated, not fixed-interest, or not guaranteed by the UK government, it would not meet the described permitted category and the general prohibition on holding investments would apply [#TGT:d83625f1bbe08d65].

question: For the term that is stated to have the meaning given in Insurance – Senior Management Functions, what is the defined scope of the With-Profits Actuary function (SMF20a), including who is advised, which firms are in scope, and what type of decisions the advice relates to?
gold_answer: Where a term is stated to “have the meaning given in Insurance – Senior Management Functions”, its content must be taken from the relevant Senior Management Functions definition rather than inferred from general usage [#SRC:b8a575708145432a]. In that cross-referenced framework, the With-Profits Actuary function (SMF20a) is defined by the responsibility it assigns: it is the function of having responsibility for advising the governing body of a firm that is transacting with-profits insurance business [#TGT:0a717d38fe9247ed]. The definition is triggered by the firm’s activity (transacting with-profits insurance business) and by the nature of the responsibility (advising the governing body). The subject matter of the advice is also defined: it concerns the exercise of discretion that affects part or all of that with-profits insurance business, so the function is tied to discretionary decisions with business impact rather than to actuarial work in general [#TGT:0a717d38fe9247ed]. The target text further indicates that this responsibility is “described more fully in Actuaries 5.1”, signalling that the definition is intended to be read consistently with that fuller description while retaining the core elements above [#TGT:0a717d38fe9247ed].

question: What must a firm do to show it has properly built current and future risk and the cost of capital into variable remuneration decisions for Solvency II staff, and how must the firm’s specific arrangements be set up to meet the required principles?
gold_answer: A firm must be able to show, with evidence, how it has taken account of the risks it faces in the short to long term and the cost of capital when it determines variable remuneration, both at an overall level and for individuals [#SRC:0743fb295f0eaa4b]. This is tied to performance measurement: the approach should include a downward adjustment for exposure to current and future risks, taking into account the undertaking’s risk profile and the cost of capital, and the firm may use risk-adjusted metrics (for example, measuring return relative to risk over a set period) and apply discretionary factors where appropriate [#SRC:0743fb295f0eaa4b]. At the same time, the firm must ensure that its specific arrangements are designed and maintained so they comply with all applicable principles governing those arrangements [#TGT:682a94015e8ea157]. In effect, the firm should ensure its arrangements translate the risk- and capital-sensitive performance measurement expectations into concrete processes and controls that can be shown to meet the full set of required principles [#TGT:682a94015e8ea157].

question: For an entity that is both an institution and an SDDT (or SDDT consolidation entity), what must it do to satisfy both the prescribed publication manner for required disclosures and the obligation to disclose the outlined information with the specified frequency?
gold_answer: If the same entity falls within both categories, it must comply with two complementary obligations: first, as an institution, it must publish the disclosures that are required under the relevant Titles, and it must do so using the manner specified for those disclosures [#SRC:a2135b9576433803]. Second, as an SDDT or SDDT consolidation entity, it must disclose the information identified in the applicable outline and must provide that information at the frequency stated for each disclosure item [#TGT:88d1ac0b109bd32f]. To satisfy both, the entity should treat “publication manner” and “disclosure frequency” as separate compliance dimensions that both apply: the publication manner governs how the required disclosures are made available, while the frequency governs when the outlined SDDT/SDDT consolidation entity information must be disclosed. Accordingly, the entity should maintain a disclosure inventory that links each required disclosure to its publication approach and, where relevant, to the required periodic schedule, ensuring timely and properly formatted publication and recurring disclosure.

question: For depositor protection purposes, how is the “applicable time period” for paying compensation defined, and in what circumstances is the FSCS permitted to defer payment beyond that defined period while still aligning with the PRA’s stated expectation on payout timing?
gold_answer: The “applicable time period” is defined as the period that begins on the day after the compensation date and ends seven business days later, which establishes the baseline window against which timeliness is assessed [#TGT:05fada0595bda499]. Within depositor protection, the FSCS is permitted to defer payment of compensation beyond the relevant time period where the circumstances set out for deferral apply, meaning that payment may occur after the baseline window when those circumstances arise [#SRC:93fa502183ec06a0]. At the same time, the PRA’s expectation is that the FSCS should aim to pay out the deposits within three months where possible, indicating that even where deferral beyond the defined applicable time period is permitted, the FSCS should still work toward completing payout within that broader three‑month aim when feasible [#SRC:93fa502183ec06a0]. The PRA also recognises that there may be circumstances in which it may not be possible for the FSCS to pay out within that three‑month timeframe, reinforcing that deferral can be relevant both to the defined applicable time period and to the PRA’s longer “where possible” expectation [#SRC:93fa502183ec06a0].

question: What does the “applicable time period” mean for paying compensation, and when can the FSCS pay later than that period under depositor protection while still aiming to meet the PRA’s timing expectation?
gold_answer: The “applicable time period” means the window that starts the day after the compensation date and finishes seven business days later, so it is a specific, defined period for measuring when compensation should be paid [#TGT:05fada0595bda499]. Depositor protection also describes that the FSCS may defer payment of compensation beyond the time period that is otherwise set out, but only in the circumstances that are set out for deferral, so paying later than the defined window is permitted when those circumstances apply [#SRC:93fa502183ec06a0]. Even where a deferral beyond the applicable time period occurs, the PRA expects the FSCS to aim to pay out the deposits within three months where possible, which provides a broader timing aim that should guide the FSCS’s approach to completing payout [#SRC:93fa502183ec06a0]. The PRA also recognises that it may not be possible for the FSCS to pay out within that three‑month timeframe in some circumstances, which helps explain why the rules contemplate deferral beyond the defined applicable time period in the first place [#SRC:93fa502183ec06a0].

question: In the context of material models, how should firms define what constitutes an exception for model use or model performance, and what governance steps must they put in place to allow such exceptions while maintaining oversight and control?
gold_answer: For material models, firms should first formulate the specific exceptions they would allow for both model use and model performance, using the definition of “exceptions” as situations such as using a model when it is not approved by the appropriate oversight entity or not validated for use, using a model outside its intended purpose, continuing to use a model with persistent breaches of performance metrics, or where back testing indicates results inconsistent with actual outcomes [#TGT:fff692c37fa26818]. Building on that definition, firms should implement formally approved policies and procedures that set out escalation procedures and how these exceptions will be managed [#SRC:7e2a5a060e5ac933]. For exceptions related to model use, firms should treat them as temporary, apply post-model adjustments (PMAs), and ensure they are reported to and supported by stakeholders and senior management [#SRC:7e2a5a060e5ac933]. For model performance exceptions, firms should establish clear guidelines to determine maximum tolerance for deviations from expectation, and apply appropriate risk controls and mitigants once defined triggers and thresholds are breached, including alternatives, heightened review and challenge, more frequent monitoring, recalibration, or redevelopment [#SRC:7e2a5a060e5ac933].

question: If a firm’s internal model uses certain methods and assumptions, what must it be able to evidence to the PRA, and what specific part of the model must it ensure complies with the stated compliance range?
gold_answer: The firm must be able to evidence to the PRA that it complies with the requirements set out in the Statistical Quality Standards (SQS) for internal models, which cover the principles that the methods and assumptions used in the internal model must adhere to [#SRC:f9ebadff53a4bf82]. This is an explicit expectation: compliance is not just about having an internal model, but about being able to demonstrate adherence to those principle-based requirements to the PRA. In addition, the firm must ensure a specific operational outcome: its internal model and, in particular, the calculation of the probability distribution forecast generated by it, complies with 11.2 to 11.13 [#TGT:3ed819cc35a6fc9d]. So the firm’s evidence should support both elements at once—showing that the methods and assumptions meet the SQS principles and that this is reflected in the compliant calculation of the probability distribution forecast within the 11.2 to 11.13 scope—so the PRA can assess compliance based on documented support rather than unsupported statements [#SRC:f9ebadff53a4bf82] [#TGT:3ed819cc35a6fc9d].

question: If you need to cite the document about enhancing banks’ and insurers’ approaches to managing the financial risks from climate change, what details should you use from the SS3/19 entry and from the Bank of England Prudential Regulation publication entry (including timing) so the citation is complete and consistent?
gold_answer: To make the citation complete and consistent, you should combine the key identifiers from the SS3/19 entry with the timing and location details from the Bank of England Prudential Regulation publication entry. From the SS3/19 record, use the document identifier “SS3/19,” keep the document title describing enhancing banks’ and insurers’ approaches to managing the financial risks from climate change, and retain the associated reference number “17,” which helps ensure you are pointing to the correct item in your internal list [#SRC:b56e255afd8a5779]. From the publication record, add the concrete date “April 2019” and include the full URL to the Prudential Regulation page where the same titled supervisory statement is published, which is also labelled with “17” in that record [#TGT:b96b25cb718f3754]. Using both sources together gives you an internally consistent identifier (SS3/19; 17) and an externally verifiable publication reference (April 2019 plus the Bank of England link).

question: How should Firms evidence that they retain and maintain all data and information reasonably necessary to support timely, robust resolution valuations, and how should that evidence be cross-referenced to the Bank’s stated expectations in its SoP on ViR?
gold_answer: Firms should be able to demonstrate, in a way that can be mapped to Paragraph 4.2(b) of The Bank’s SoP on ViR [#TGT:22a52eecee35258f], that they hold all relevant data and information reasonably necessary to enable timely and robust resolution valuations [#SRC:ba44d02feeb16342]. This should include data needed to value trading positions (including hedging and liquidity management positions) and the related information on investment securities, repo transactions, and derivatives, together with the collateral, netting, and set-off arrangements applicable to those exposures [#SRC:ba44d02feeb16342]. Firms should also show that the data and information are sufficiently up to date, taking into account how quickly underlying positions could change in the lead up to resolution [#SRC:ba44d02feeb16342]. In addition, Firms should be prepared to evidence that valuation models and forecasting capabilities are available in business-as-usual for material asset and liability classes and for producing updated forecasts of financial statements and key regulatory metrics on a timely basis, including support for a restructuring plan where relevant [#SRC:ba44d02feeb16342], and that these arrangements align to the expectations referenced in Paragraph 4.2(b) [#TGT:22a52eecee35258f].

question: Where Firms rely on valuation models and forecasting capabilities in business-as-usual to support resolution valuations, what specific categories of positions and arrangements must be covered, and which Bank SoP reference should be used to anchor the internal policy mapping?
gold_answer: Firms should ensure their business-as-usual capabilities cover the full set of data and information that would reasonably be considered necessary for timely and robust resolution valuations [#SRC:ba44d02feeb16342], and they should anchor their internal policy mapping to Paragraph 4.2(b) of The Bank’s SoP on ViR [#TGT:22a52eecee35258f]. Concretely, the scope should extend to producing robust valuations of a firm’s trading positions, including those used for hedging and liquidity management [#SRC:ba44d02feeb16342]. It should also include information on investment securities, repo transactions, and derivatives, and the collateral, netting, and set-off arrangements applicable to these exposures [#SRC:ba44d02feeb16342]. Firms should be able to show that their data are sufficiently up to date given the speed at which positions could change in the lead up to resolution [#SRC:ba44d02feeb16342]. They should also maintain valuation models for all material classes of assets and liabilities where it is not reasonable to expect a suitably robust model could be developed and deployed on a timely basis in the lead up to resolution, and maintain forecasting capabilities to produce updated forecasts of financial statements and key regulatory metrics on a timely basis [#SRC:ba44d02feeb16342], with the cross-reference to Paragraph 4.2(b) [#TGT:22a52eecee35258f].

question: If a Firm says its valuation models and forecasts are ready in normal operations, what should it be able to show about keeping data current and covering key exposures, and what Bank SoP paragraph should it point to?
gold_answer: A Firm should be able to show that it keeps all relevant data and information needed for timely and robust resolution valuations [#SRC:ba44d02feeb16342], and it should point to Paragraph 4.2(b) of The Bank’s SoP on ViR as the cross-reference for that expectation [#TGT:22a52eecee35258f]. The Firm should be able to evidence that its data are sufficiently up to date, taking into account the speed at which underlying positions could change in the lead up to resolution [#SRC:ba44d02feeb16342]. It should also be able to show that the data set covers the exposures and arrangements that drive valuation: trading positions (including hedging and liquidity management), investment securities, repo transactions, and derivatives, plus the collateral, netting, and set-off arrangements applicable to those exposures [#SRC:ba44d02feeb16342]. Beyond data coverage, the Firm should be able to demonstrate that valuation models are available in business-as-usual for all material classes of assets and liabilities where it is not reasonable to expect a robust model could be developed and deployed on a timely basis in the lead up to resolution [#SRC:ba44d02feeb16342]. It should also maintain forecasting capabilities in business-as-usual to produce updated forecasts of financial statements and key regulatory metrics on a timely basis, including support for a restructuring plan where relevant [#SRC:ba44d02feeb16342], and map these to Paragraph 4.2(b) [#TGT:22a52eecee35258f].

question: When do the “the firm must” requirements apply if the earlier rules don’t apply, and does this cover cases where a non-firm group member (included in the firm’s consolidated supervision) intends to do something?
gold_answer: The “the firm must” requirement applies in the specific situation where the earlier provisions are not applicable because they are switched off by the stated condition, and the text then directs that the firm must follow the alternative requirement that applies in that circumstance [#SRC:8034e440849d1fe7]. To know whether you are in the right fact pattern to consider that obligation, you also need to apply the scope statement: it covers not only where the firm itself intends to take the relevant action, but also where another member of its group intends to do so, as long as that group member is not a firm and is included in the supervision on a consolidated basis of the firm [#TGT:5b0e063773d65dd0]. Putting both together, you assess (1) whether the intended action is by the firm or by a qualifying non-firm group member within consolidated supervision, and then (2) whether the earlier provisions are disapplied; if they are, the firm must comply with the substitute requirement that is stated to apply in that case.

question: In a group solvency calculation, what must be left out unless it can cover the related undertaking’s SCR, and how do you make sure the total own funds you include does not go above that related Solvency II undertaking’s SCR?
gold_answer: For the group solvency calculation, the rule requires that certain items are excluded unless they are eligible to cover the SCR of the related undertaking concerned, and even then they can be included only to the extent of that eligibility [#TGT:d68b868d9faa51ba]. At the same time, there is a separate limit on how much own funds can be included: the sum of the own funds included under the specified inclusion categories must not exceed the SCR of the related Solvency II undertaking [#SRC:d8e1f257c79a1b03]. Putting these together, you should treat the group calculation as having two controls: first, an eligibility gate (exclude by default; include only if eligible for covering the related undertaking’s SCR, and only up to the eligible amount), and second, a total cap (even eligible included own funds must be kept within the related undertaking’s SCR). This ensures the group does not count amounts that either are not eligible for SCR coverage or that exceed the SCR limit for the related undertaking.

question: For compliance referencing of SS4/17 on cyber insurance underwriting risk, how should an Authorised Person align the Source identifier with the Bank of England Prudential Regulation publication record, including the applicable publication date and the specific web location?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person should treat the Source identifier as the authoritative label for the supervisory statement and then cross-reference it to the Bank of England Prudential Regulation publication record to ensure the correct document is being cited and retrieved. Specifically, the Source establishes that the relevant instrument is SS4/17 titled “Cyber insurance underwriting risk” and indicates the associated item marker “6” [#SRC:21cc1918a8d42fec]. The Target then provides the corresponding publication entry details needed to operationalise that reference: it links the same “cyber-insurance-underwriting-risk-ss” supervisory statement to a dated publication record of November 2024 and supplies the exact Bank of England URL path under prudential regulation publications (www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2017/cyber-insurance-underwriting-risk-ss) [#TGT:f2cec20aa1033a33]. Read together, the Source identifier (SS4/17; item “6”) and the Target’s dated web record (November 2024; the specified URL) provide a complete, auditable citation package for cyber insurance underwriting risk materials.

question: If you need to look up the Bank of England page for SS4/17 on cyber insurance underwriting risk, what details from the Source and the Target should you use, including the date shown and the exact link?
gold_answer: Use the Source to confirm you have the right supervisory statement name and identifier, and use the Target to locate the official Bank of England Prudential Regulation web record and its date. The Source tells you the relevant document is SS4/17 on “Cyber insurance underwriting risk” and associates it with the item marker “6,” which helps you match it to the correct entry [#SRC:21cc1918a8d42fec]. The Target then gives the practical lookup information: it shows a publication record dated November 2024 and provides the exact Bank of England URL where the supervisory statement can be accessed (www.bankofengland.co.uk/prudential-regulation/publication/2017/cyber-insurance-underwriting-risk-ss) [#TGT:f2cec20aa1033a33]. Combining these, you can (1) verify the title and identifier from the Source, and (2) use the Target’s November 2024 date and the precise link to retrieve and cite the correct cyber insurance underwriting risk supervisory statement.

question: Given that the Operational Resilience Parts of the PRA Rulebook and SS1/21 set expectations around identifying important business services and setting impact tolerances, what actions must firms take to ensure they can continue delivering those services within tolerances, and how does the March 2021 SS1/21 publication link inform where the relevant supervisory material is located?
gold_answer: Firms are required and expected, under the Operational Resilience Parts of the PRA Rulebook and SS1/21, to identify their important business services and set impact tolerances for those services, and then to take action to ensure they are able to deliver those important business services within the impact tolerances they have set [#SRC:f9622b5d346bca89]. A key means of doing so is testing against severe but plausible operational disruption scenarios, which enables firms to identify vulnerabilities and take mitigating action; where deficiencies are found, the PRA’s operational resilience policy requires boards and senior management to drive improvement [#SRC:f9622b5d346bca89]. The TARGET provides the concrete publication timing and location for the SS1/21 material—specifically “March 2021” and the Bank of England webpage link—so a firm can evidence that it is using the correct supervisory statement when aligning its identification of services, impact tolerances, testing, mitigation, and governance-driven remediation activities with the PRA’s expectations [#TGT:1553145ecbcbd731].

question: When supervisors identify deficiencies in a firm’s management, governance, or culture and supervisory intensity is escalated, how is the PRA’s expectation that the firm must take remedial action over a defined period framed in the supervisory approach materials referenced in the related cross-citation?
gold_answer: Where supervisors identify deficiencies in a firm’s management and/or governance practices, including cultural deficiencies, the PRA indicates that the Proactive Intervention Framework (PIF) stage may change and that supervisory intensity will increase, potentially including additional reporting requirements and the use of additional information-gathering powers. In that escalated context, the PRA states it will require the firm to act to address the identified deficiencies over a set period [#SRC:0ef314f548192f59]. The related cross-citation points to the PRA’s approach to banking supervision (June 2014) and the PRA’s approach to insurance supervision (June 2014), specifically Table A in each document, as the referenced supervisory approach materials that sit alongside and support this statement of supervisory expectations [#TGT:0bfe43c820470003]. Read together, the statement describes the trigger (identified deficiencies) and the supervisory consequences (intensified supervision and a required remediation timeframe), while the cross-cited approach documents are the designated sources for the PRA’s broader supervisory approach framework that contextualises how such requirements are situated within its supervision of banking and insurance firms.

question: After 01/01/2027, under the future market risk exposure disclosure rules, if Institutions calculate their own funds requirements using the specified methods, what exactly must they break out in their disclosure, and do they need a separate line for securitisation interest rate risk?
gold_answer: In the future version of the rules on disclosure of exposure to market risk that applies after 01/01/2027, Institutions that calculate their own funds requirements using the specified methods must not disclose only a single combined number. Instead, they must split the disclosure so that the own funds requirements are shown separately for each risk that is covered by those methods, allowing readers to see the requirement attributable to each relevant risk category. Beyond that general requirement to disclose by risk, Institutions must also make an additional separate disclosure for the own funds requirements relating to the specific interest rate risk of securitisation positions. That securitisation-specific interest rate risk amount must be presented distinctly, not merely embedded within another risk disclosure. These disclosure expectations are tied to the future market risk exposure disclosure regime after 01/01/2027 [#SRC:b7e47ffae39566a1] and are mandatory for Institutions that meet the condition of calculating own funds requirements in the manner described [#TGT:acd7395abbe27295].

question: What must a firm do to have good governance for its own business, and what extra step is required if it is part of a group under group supervision so governance and reporting can be controlled at group level?
gold_answer: A firm must have an effective system of governance in place that enables sound and prudent management of its business [#TGT:b4d0f4b56df92dd6]. If the firm sits within a group that includes other undertakings in the scope of group supervision, the obligation goes further: the effective system of governance and the related reporting procedures must be implemented consistently across all those undertakings [#SRC:81456a787f326c75].
