This is not just a documentation requirement; it is about applying the same governance and reporting approach throughout the supervised group so that the system and procedures can be controlled at the level of the group, rather than being fragmented or managed only within individual entities [#SRC:81456a787f326c75]. In practice, the firm must therefore both establish governance that supports prudent management for itself and ensure consistent roll-out and operation of governance and reporting procedures across the supervised group to enable group-level control [#TGT:b4d0f4b56df92dd6] [#SRC:81456a787f326c75].

question: Where a firm has not elected monthly reporting of changes in close links, what must it (or another firm in its group) do to make the required notification, including the required method, timing, and the information that must be provided?
gold_answer: If a firm has not elected to report changes in close links on a monthly basis, it must make a notification (or procure that another firm in its group makes it) by completing the Close Links Notification Form. The notification must be made as soon as reasonably practicable and, in any event, no later than one month after the firm becomes aware that it has begun to have, or has ceased to have, close links with any person [#TGT:a5839d75335755c9]. In addition to using the specified form, the notification must include all the relevant information specified in that Close Links Notification Form, meaning the firm (or the group firm submitting on its behalf) must ensure the form is completed with the full set of required particulars rather than providing a partial or informal notice [#SRC:d6fa5c79c4012dd5]. Read together, the obligations establish both the mandatory submission mechanism (completion of the Close Links Notification Form) and the minimum content standard (all relevant information specified in the form), alongside the deadline triggered by the firm’s awareness of the start or cessation of close links.

question: If a Solvency II firm is checking what rules apply to its business, group oversight, and investments, how do the PRA Rulebook scope statement and the Bank of England publication date work together, and what date should the firm note?
gold_answer: The scope text indicates that the relevant material is the Conditions Governing Business, Group Supervision, and Investments Parts of the PRA Rulebook and that these Parts are framed “for Solvency II firms,” so the firm should start by treating those Parts as the core set of requirements and expectations that apply to it as a Solvency II firm [#SRC:56f29c704727d130]. The related Bank of England Prudential Regulation reference then adds a concrete timing marker by listing “November 2024” alongside a publication link, which the firm should record as the relevant date when organizing its compliance review and update cycle [#TGT:bfd971bbd95f6347]. Used together, the scope statement tells the firm which population and subject areas are in view (business conditions, group supervision, and investments), while the dated publication reference provides a clear point in time to anchor internal planning—such as scheduling policy refreshes, governance checks, and evidence gathering—so the firm can show it considered the November 2024 reference when applying the scoped PRA Rulebook Parts.

question: How must an insurer’s obligation to hold liquid assets of adequate amount and quality to meet liabilities as they fall due be reflected in the firm’s required policies within the areas it must ensure are included, particularly in relation to assessing liquidity needs and sources under both normal and stressed conditions?
gold_answer: An insurer is expected to treat the maintenance of sufficient liquid assets—both in amount and in quality—as a core outcome that its internal policies must support, because this liquidity position is required to enable the insurer to meet liabilities as they fall due [#SRC:297334dc210e644c]. To operationalise that obligation, a firm must ensure that the relevant areas include all required policies, so the policy set should be structured to capture and govern how liquidity is assessed, sourced, and maintained across the business [#TGT:c1d8710f1b39fcc3]. In practice, this means the policies included in those areas should require a critical examination of liquidity needs and sources not only in benign circumstances but also under stress, and should drive consideration of liquidity risk exposure in normal market conditions and in severe but plausible stressed situations, including general market-wide turbulence, idiosyncratic difficulties, and combinations of both [#SRC:297334dc210e644c]. The firm’s obligation to ensure inclusion of all such policies provides the governance mechanism through which these liquidity expectations are embedded and consistently applied [#TGT:c1d8710f1b39fcc3].

question: What does a firm have to build into its required policies so that an insurer can keep enough high-quality liquid assets to pay liabilities on time, including when markets are stressed?
gold_answer: The insurer must be able to meet liabilities as they fall due by maintaining sufficient liquid assets, and this sufficiency is about both the amount held and the quality of those assets [#SRC:297334dc210e644c]. To make that requirement workable in day-to-day governance, a firm must ensure that the relevant areas include all required policies, meaning the firm’s policy framework must explicitly cover how liquidity is identified, monitored, and supported across the business [#TGT:c1d8710f1b39fcc3]. Those policies should require the insurer to critically examine its liquidity needs and sources in benign circumstances and under stress, and they should reflect the expectation that liquidity risk exposure is considered in normal market conditions and also in severe but plausible stressed situations [#SRC:297334dc210e644c]. The stress considerations should include scenarios driven by general market-wide turbulence, idiosyncratic difficulties, and combinations of both, so that the policies included in the required areas drive consistent preparation for both routine and adverse conditions [#SRC:297334dc210e644c] while satisfying the obligation to include all such policies [#TGT:c1d8710f1b39fcc3].

question: When assessing whether the firm can absorb the full costs of a solvent exit and meet all liabilities to depositors (and other creditors as applicable), how should the firm’s planning address both the adequacy of its financial resources (capital, funding, and liquidity) under realistic exit valuations and the possibility that it anticipates using the Bank of England’s lending facilities?
gold_answer: The firm should demonstrate that its financial resources—capital, funding, and liquidity—are sufficient to absorb the full costs of a solvent exit and to meet all liabilities to depositors (and other creditors as applicable), based on realistic exit valuations of assets and liabilities and supported by appropriate analysis. That analysis should include sensitivity analyses of factors that may affect the resources needed and a review of balance sheet items that may be difficult to transfer or sell after the main deposit and lending books have been disposed of [#SRC:35122617de21cc35]. In parallel, the firm’s planning should explicitly consider whether it anticipates using the Bank of England’s lending facilities (for example, the Discount Window Facility), because that expectation is part of what is included in the relevant assessment and should be addressed as a distinct planning assumption alongside internal resources [#TGT:29aef3477fc07890]. Taken together, the firm should present a coherent picture of how it would fund and execute the exit under stressed and plausible conditions, and how any anticipated central bank facility usage fits within (and does not substitute for) the overall resource sufficiency analysis.

question: If a firm says it can cover all the costs of a solvent exit and pay depositors and other creditors, what should it show about its own capital, funding, and liquidity analysis, and how should it deal with any expectation that it will use Bank of England lending facilities?
gold_answer: The firm should show, with evidence, that it has enough financial resources—capital, funding, and liquidity—to absorb the full costs of a solvent exit and meet all liabilities to depositors (and other creditors as applicable). That showing should be grounded in realistic exit valuations of its assets and liabilities and supported by appropriate analysis, including sensitivity analyses of factors that could change the amount of resources needed. It should also include an analysis of any balance sheet items that may be difficult to transfer or sell after the main deposit and lending books have been disposed of, because those items can affect both timing and the amount of liquidity or funding required [#SRC:35122617de21cc35]. Separately, the firm should address whether it anticipates using the Bank of England’s lending facilities (for example, the Discount Window Facility), since this expectation is explicitly included in the relevant consideration and should be stated clearly as part of the firm’s exit planning assumptions [#TGT:29aef3477fc07890]. The combined explanation should make clear how internal resources and any anticipated facility use interact in the exit plan.

question: Where the court’s order requires that notice or notices be published and sent in accordance with that order, what must the applicant(s) do to ensure the PRA receives the relevant order, and when must this be done?
gold_answer: When the court has made an order that governs how notice or notices are to be published and sent, the applicant(s) must treat that court order as the controlling procedural basis for the publication and sending steps, i.e., the notices must be published and sent in accordance with the order of the court [#SRC:0c75723605fbfaff]. In parallel with implementing those notice steps, the applicant(s) have an obligation to provide the PRA with a copy of any order made at the directions hearing, and the timing expectation is that this should be done as soon as the order is available [#TGT:d645550e406018f5]. Practically, this means the applicant(s) should not wait until after notices are published and sent to share the order with the PRA; instead, once the directions-hearing order exists and can be obtained, the applicant(s) should promptly transmit a copy to the PRA so the PRA has the same operative document that dictates the manner in which the notices are to be issued. This aligns the applicant(s)’ procedural compliance with the court’s order and their prompt provision of the order to the PRA.

question: What does a third country branch need to do regularly to test its business continuity policy, and how should it use those test results to check whether its systems and internal controls are working well and fix problems?
gold_answer: A third country branch needs to carry out regular testing of its business continuity policy, and it must do so in an appropriate manner [#SRC:021e247577a92f56]. Those tests should not be treated as a standalone exercise: the branch should use the outcomes as part of its regular process to monitor and evaluate whether its systems, internal control mechanisms and arrangements are adequate and effective [#TGT:f6ce43c92e5bba55]. In other words, continuity testing should feed into the branch’s broader, ongoing review of how well its governance and operational arrangements are functioning. If the testing shows that continuity arrangements do not work as intended, or that controls and arrangements are not effective, the branch must take appropriate measures to address the deficiencies identified [#TGT:f6ce43c92e5bba55]. This links the “regular testing” requirement with a continuous improvement loop: test regularly and appropriately, evaluate what the results say about adequacy and effectiveness, and then implement remediation so weaknesses are corrected rather than repeated in subsequent testing cycles [#SRC:021e247577a92f56] [#TGT:f6ce43c92e5bba55].

question: When this Part is intended to operate on a group basis, how should the compliance perimeter be set where the participating Solvency II undertaking or the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company is itself a subsidiary undertaking of another Solvency II undertaking or another insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company with its head office in the UK or Gibraltar? In that scenario, does the group-wide composition of “all undertakings within the relevant group” still apply, or is the application constrained to the ultimate UK or Gibraltar head-office entity for the specified provisions?
gold_answer: Where this Part applies at the level of a group, the baseline scope is that the group consists of all undertakings within the relevant group, subject to the stated qualifications and conditions in the scope provision [#SRC:5b84eae896bfe57f]. However, the TARGET text introduces a specific limitation when the participating Solvency II undertaking or the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company is itself a subsidiary undertaking of another Solvency II undertaking or another insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company with its head office in the UK or Gibraltar. In that case, the identified set of provisions (4 to 19) do not apply at the level of the subsidiary; instead, they apply only at the level of the ultimate Solvency II undertaking, insurance holding company, or mixed financial holding company in the group that has its head office in the UK or Gibraltar [#TGT:5d7d86c6c088b08d]. Read together, this means you start from the group-wide perimeter concept (all undertakings within the relevant group) but, for those provisions, you must anchor application at the ultimate UK/Gibraltar head-office entity rather than at an intermediate subsidiary level.

question: If this Part is meant to apply to a group, does it cover all undertakings in the relevant group even when the participating Solvency II undertaking or the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company is a subsidiary of another UK or Gibraltar head-office group entity? Or, in that case, do the rules apply only at the level of the ultimate Solvency II undertaking, insurance holding company, or mixed financial holding company?
gold_answer: The SOURCE sets the general scope concept for group application: when this Part applies at the level of a group, the group is defined to consist of all undertakings within the relevant group, subject to the stated qualifications and conditions in that scope statement [#SRC:5b84eae896bfe57f]. The TARGET then narrows how certain provisions operate in a specific ownership structure. If the participating Solvency II undertaking or the insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company is itself a subsidiary undertaking of another Solvency II undertaking or another insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company with its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, then the provisions identified as 4 to 19 apply only at the level of the ultimate Solvency II undertaking, insurance holding company, or mixed financial holding company in the group that has its head office in the UK or Gibraltar [#TGT:5d7d86c6c088b08d]. Putting both together: the framework assumes a group-wide perimeter (all undertakings in the relevant group), but for those provisions, you apply them only at the ultimate UK/Gibraltar head-office level when the entity in question sits under another UK/Gibraltar-headed parent.

question: How must the firm ensure that the policies and procedures it establishes, implements and maintains to detect risks of non-compliance remain adequate and effective over time, including how it must monitor them and address deficiencies?
gold_answer: The firm must take a lifecycle approach that links creation of its compliance framework with ongoing oversight. First, it must establish, implement and maintain adequate policies and procedures that are designed to detect any risk that the firm may fail to comply with its obligations under the regulatory system, and to detect associated risks [#TGT:99eb8123bfeb79db]. Second, once those measures are in place, the firm must monitor them on a permanent basis and assess on a regular basis whether the measures, policies and procedures remain adequate and effective, rather than treating them as static documents [#SRC:ee9f6727d198f98e]. This ongoing assessment must also cover the actions taken to address any deficiencies in the firm’s compliance with its obligations, meaning the firm should not only identify weaknesses but also evaluate whether remediation steps are implemented and working as intended [#SRC:ee9f6727d198f98e]. Together, these requirements mean the firm must both design controls to detect non-compliance risks and continuously test, review, and improve those controls to ensure they continue to detect risks and support compliance outcomes [#TGT:99eb8123bfeb79db].

question: How must an insurer align its obligation to establish, implement, and maintain written risk management policies and procedures with the expectation to review its limits at least annually as part of the broader review of its risk management policies, including making adjustments when risk tolerances or market conditions change?
gold_answer: An insurer must ensure its written governance framework for risk management is not static: it should be established, implemented, and maintained through documented policies and adequate procedures covering at least risk management (and also internal control, internal audit, and where relevant outsourcing) [#TGT:223fc6e5205a9c72]. In parallel, the insurer is expected to regularly review its limits and make appropriate adjustments when its risk tolerances or broader market conditions change, so the written risk management policies and procedures should support and evidence that ongoing monitoring and adjustment process [#SRC:a810e349d072127d]. For an insurer other than a small non-Directive insurer, the expectation includes reviewing these limits at least annually as part of the broader review of its risk management policies, meaning the insurer should embed an annual review cycle into its maintained written risk management documentation and procedures, and ensure that outcomes (e.g., limit changes driven by tolerance shifts or market conditions) are reflected in the maintained policies and procedures [#SRC:a810e349d072127d] and remain adequate under the written-policy requirement [#TGT:223fc6e5205a9c72].

question: What does an insurer need to do to keep its written risk management policies and procedures up to date if it is expected to review its limits regularly and, for most insurers, at least once a year as part of its wider risk management policy review?
gold_answer: An insurer must have written policies and adequate procedures in place for at least risk management (as well as internal control, internal audit, and where relevant outsourcing), and it must establish, implement, and maintain them over time [#TGT:223fc6e5205a9c72]. Separately, the insurer is expected to regularly review its limits and adjust them when its risk tolerances or broader market conditions change, which means the insurer’s written risk management policies and procedures should be maintained in a way that supports those reviews and captures resulting changes [#SRC:a810e349d072127d]. In addition, an insurer other than a small non-Directive insurer should review these limits at least annually as part of the broader review of its risk management policies, so the insurer should build an annual review step into its maintained documentation and procedures and ensure the written materials are updated to reflect any revised limits and the reasons for adjustment [#SRC:a810e349d072127d]. This ties the ongoing and annual limit-review expectation to the continuing obligation to maintain adequate written risk management policies and procedures [#TGT:223fc6e5205a9c72].

question: When a firm proposes to amend its model change policy (beyond administrative updates), how should it treat that amendment in terms of PRA permission, and what dated PRA publication should it consult for the relevant context on changes to internal models?
gold_answer: A firm should treat any change to the model change policy itself—other than purely administrative changes—as a matter that is subject to the PRA’s permission, meaning the firm should not proceed on the basis that it is automatically covered by existing arrangements. This sits alongside the PRA’s expectation that firms regularly review the effectiveness of the model change policy so the internal model continues to reflect the firm’s risk profile and continues to meet internal model requirements and calibration standards [#SRC:c52cdc2f44519224]. For the relevant context on changes to internal models used by UK insurance firms, the firm should consult the PRA publication identified as SS12/16, which is dated September 2016 [#TGT:34ad566f87cce998]. Read together, these points indicate that governance over the model change policy is not merely procedural: substantive amendments to the policy are treated as permissioned changes, and the September 2016 publication is the referenced source for further detail on the broader topic of changes to internal models.

question: When the PRA receives a written representation or notice in connection with the merger confirmation procedures described in the appendix, what procedural steps must the PRA follow to confirm receipt and ensure the relevant parties are informed and able to respond?
gold_answer: Where a written representation or notice is submitted to the PRA for the merger confirmation process, the PRA must take several sequenced steps that align the acknowledgement obligation with the appendix’s procedural purpose. First, the PRA must acknowledge receipt of each representation or notice, ensuring the representer has confirmation that the submission has been received. Next, the PRA must send the representer a copy of the appendix on merger confirmation procedures, which is expressly intended for those making written representations to the PRA and/or those participating in oral confirmation hearings and sets out the procedures the PRA intends to follow [#TGT:9361b73623bf63a6]. In addition, the PRA must send copies of all written representations to the societies concerned and must afford those societies an opportunity to comment on the representations, so that the process includes a response opportunity for the affected societies. Taken together, these steps operationalise the PRA’s intended procedures by combining receipt acknowledgement, provision of the procedural appendix to the representer, and circulation plus comment opportunity for the societies concerned [#SRC:8e78e2017ace2c0e].

question: If someone sends a written representation to the PRA, what must the PRA do to confirm it got it and to share the relevant procedure information, and how are the societies concerned brought into the process?
gold_answer: If a person makes a written representation (or sends a notice) to the PRA in this context, the PRA must follow a set of actions that connect receipt handling with the procedures the PRA intends to follow. The PRA must acknowledge the receipt of each representation or notice so the representer knows it has been received. The PRA must also send the representer a copy of the appendix on merger confirmation procedures, which is specifically for people making written representations to the PRA and/or those taking part in oral confirmation hearings and explains the procedures the PRA intends to follow [#TGT:9361b73623bf63a6]. Beyond communicating with the representer, the PRA must send copies of all written representations to the societies concerned. The PRA must then give those societies an opportunity to comment on the written representations, ensuring they can respond as part of the process. In short, the PRA confirms receipt, provides the procedural appendix to the representer, and circulates the written representations to the societies concerned with a chance to comment, reflecting both the PRA’s obligations and the appendix’s procedural role [#SRC:8e78e2017ace2c0e].

question: How must an insurer’s liquidity risk monitoring and reporting arrangements be designed and operated so that they both meet the expectation for clear, timely and accurate liquidity risk reporting to relevant functions and also sit within the firm’s overarching requirement to maintain an effective system of governance for sound and prudent management of its business?
gold_answer: An insurer should treat liquidity risk monitoring and reporting as a core component of its broader governance framework. The insurer is expected to establish systems for the management of risk and to put in place reporting processes and procedures so that necessary information is available to decision-makers; within that context, the PRA expects an effective system of monitoring and reporting liquidity risk that produces clear, concise, timely and accurate liquidity risk reports to relevant functions, and reflects that liquidity risks are often fast moving [#SRC:c6c19d84cebb7ce5]. In parallel, the firm must maintain an effective system of governance that provides for sound and prudent management of its business, which sets the overarching standard that the liquidity reporting system must support and be consistent with [#TGT:0e5f014b1f6ff2b1]. Practically, this means the liquidity reporting system should be embedded in governance so that relevant functions receive appropriate reports quickly enough to respond to rapidly changing liquidity conditions, and the reporting processes should ensure information quality and availability for decision-makers as part of prudent business management [#SRC:c6c19d84cebb7ce5] [#TGT:0e5f014b1f6ff2b1].

question: If a firm follows the PRA’s expanded expectations for internal credit assessments, what does it need to do next with the assessment result, and what key distinction does the PRA require the firm to keep in mind?
gold_answer: After applying the PRA’s expanded expectations for internal credit assessments (as indicated by the PRA’s statement that these expectations are expanded in the referenced material) [#SRC:e46640365e209635], a firm needs to take the resulting internal credit assessment outcome and map it onto a CQS [#TGT:db1aa8c4f1ce4333]. The PRA also requires the firm to keep a clear distinction between (1) performing an internal credit assessment and (2) mapping an asset onto a CQS, because these are two separate processes and should not be treated as the same activity [#TGT:db1aa8c4f1ce4333]. When carrying out the mapping for each internally rated asset type, the firm should consider how it has met the credit rating comparability requirements when selecting appropriate CQS mapping scales from those applicable to different CRAs, and it should be aware that the mappings of CRA credit ratings to CQSs are set out in the identified PRA Rulebook materials [#TGT:db1aa8c4f1ce4333].

question: In the context of Insurance - Fitness and Propriety, what processes and procedures must a firm maintain to support ongoing suitability by ensuring that its best estimate and the assumptions used to calculate it are routinely tested against actual experience?
gold_answer: Within the scope signposted as “Insurance - Fitness and Propriety,” a firm must operationalize that suitability focus through concrete governance and control arrangements around its actuarial or valuation work. Specifically, the firm is required to maintain processes and procedures that ensure the best estimate and the assumptions used to calculate that best estimate are not treated as static, but are regularly checked against actual experience and outcomes. This means the firm must embed an ongoing comparison mechanism—supported by documented procedures—so that experience data is used to validate whether the best estimate and its underlying assumptions remain appropriate over time, and to trigger review where experience indicates divergence. The obligation is framed as a “must” requirement on the firm to have these processes and procedures in place, and the comparison must occur on a regular basis rather than ad hoc. This aligns the Insurance - Fitness and Propriety context in the source with the operational control requirement in the target, linking propriety and fitness expectations to disciplined, experience-based monitoring of key estimation assumptions [#SRC:1fe3558db5a4bfed] [#TGT:656d998a79e6eb2c].

question: When determining the FS after a stress, how should a firm reconcile the PRA’s expectation that it should not rely on a purely formulaic re-run of the TP-based method with the PRA’s statement that there are multiple high-level drivers for why the FS may change post-stress?
gold_answer: A firm should treat the post-stress FS as an outcome that may need to change for multiple, distinct reasons, and therefore avoid simply re-applying the same assumptions, parameters, and methodology used to calculate TPs as a proxy for the stressed FS. The PRA’s expectation is that internal models used for this assessment should not be inappropriately constrained by TP-calibration choices, because a purely mechanistic re-run is unlikely to produce an SCR that reflects all quantifiable risks the firm is exposed to, including losses not allowed for within the TP calculation; this can lead to an FS that fails to capture all retained risks under stressed conditions. This need for a broader, non-mechanistic assessment aligns with the PRA’s identification of several high-level reasons why the FS could change following a stress, which implies firms should actively consider different drivers rather than assume invariance. In practice, this means revisiting stressed cash flow projections and the uncertainty around them, particularly for assets with HP cash flows, and ensuring the resulting SCR/FS reflects risks beyond those embedded in TP calculations, consistent with the PRA’s framing [#SRC:b14c4bb9bd6bb8fe] and its high-level post-stress change rationale [#TGT:9e4bd44c6341ccd9].

question: After the Transfer Resolutions are passed and the society applies to the PRA for confirmation, what should the scrutineers’ report say about any problems with the voting process, and how does that fit into the PRA’s usual steps for handling a confirmation application (including notice and any hearing)?
gold_answer: After the necessary Transfer Resolutions have been passed, the society must apply to the PRA for confirmation of the transfer in the way the PRA directs, and the transfer cannot take effect unless and until the PRA confirms it [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5]. As part of putting that application together and supporting the PRA’s review, the PRA expect the scrutineers’ report to address process quality: it should comment on any procedural difficulties encountered during the voting, and if invalid votes look significant, it should analyse why votes were treated as invalid [#SRC:1d201d12e7ea00d0]. This information should be ready in time to support the application form and public notice stage described by the PRA, and to inform the PRA’s consideration of the application under its customary procedure, including where representations are heard [#TGT:22dea1e31d8e0cd5]. In other words, the scrutineers’ report is a key input to the confirmation process because it documents any procedural issues and explains anomalies (like invalid votes) that could become relevant when the PRA assesses the application and considers any representations.

question: Where a third country firm has a UK establishment, what must the firm do to ensure workers can use an internal disclosure channel, including the steps to both set up and sustain the channel and to provide the necessary channel information to the third country firm in the UK?
gold_answer: The firm must take coordinated steps that address both the existence of an internal reporting route and its practical accessibility to workers in the third country firm’s UK establishment. First, the firm must establish, implement and maintain arrangements that are appropriate and effective for the internal disclosure of reportable concerns by a person, including a firm’s employee, using a specific channel that is independent and autonomous; this is the baseline requirement to have a functioning internal channel and to keep it operating over time [#TGT:e1060de75b1384d6]. In addition, where the relevant workforce sits within a third country firm’s UK establishment, the firm must provide information to the third country firm in the UK about that channel and must make the channel available to workers in that UK establishment, so that workers can actually access and use the internal route in practice [#SRC:ac7d95fab418408e]. Together, these obligations require both (i) maintaining an effective independent internal channel and (ii) ensuring the third country firm in the UK is informed and its UK establishment workers can use the channel.

question: How should a TWD firm use the Bank’s SoPs to meet the rule that it must be prepared for resolution, given that the PRA is consulted on the policies but does not directly supervise against them?
gold_answer: The TARGET sets the core obligation: a firm must prepare for resolution so that, if the need arises, it can be resolved in an orderly manner with a minimum disruption of critical services [#TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0]. The SOURCE explains that the PRA does not directly supervise against the Bank’s SoPs on RP, ViR, FiR, FMI or MGC, but the PRA is consulted in the development of these policies and the Bank’s approach promotes the PRA’s safety and soundness objective [#SRC:074698c4d940ed52]. For a TWD firm, that means the Bank’s SoPs can be used as a structured way to build and evidence practical resolution preparedness that is consistent with the approach designed to support the PRA’s objective, even if the supervisory relationship is not framed as direct supervision “against” the SoPs [#SRC:074698c4d940ed52]. The SOURCE further states that implementing these SoPs will help TWD firms develop and execute the TWD option in post-resolution restructuring, which supports the firm’s ability to carry out resolution actions in an orderly way when needed and thereby reduce disruption to critical services [#SRC:074698c4d940ed52; #TGT:ba7a108ec58f63f0].

question: If an institution is a small CRR firm and is covered by the relevant paragraph, what does it have to disclose about its remuneration policy and practices for staff who can materially affect the institution’s risk profile, and how does the modified approach change what it must do?
gold_answer: The institution must check whether it is within the scope described: it must be an institution that is subject to the relevant paragraph and it must be a small CRR firm. If it meets those conditions, then the disclosure required for the information referred to in Article 450 is subject to a modification, meaning the institution must follow the modified disclosure approach set out for that situation rather than treating the Article 450-related disclosure as unchanged [#SRC:42a2b094dfeedd7d]. At the same time, the institution still has a clear disclosure duty about its remuneration policy and practices for the categories of staff whose professional activities have a material impact on the institution’s risk profile. That duty is framed as a requirement to disclose the specified information regarding those policies and practices for that staff population [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0]. So, the scope text tells you when the special (modified) disclosure approach applies (small CRR firm within the paragraph), and the obligation text tells you what topic and which staff categories the disclosure must cover.

question: If someone has two different life events that create temporary high balances, how do you work out the maximum payout, and when would there be no maximum at all?
gold_answer: You start with the rule that the maximum compensation sum payable for a temporary high balance is £1,400,000, but you must also apply the exception that no limit applies to compensation payable for a temporary high balance arising from a payment in connection with personal injury or incapacity, and the rule is expressed as being subject to a qualification [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87]. Then you apply the PRA’s view on how temporary high balance protection is measured: it applies to each depositor on a per event per authorised entity basis and is intended to apply only to natural persons (individuals), not to companies [#SRC:9452d37938f9afef]. Where an individual (or a trustee in the trust situations described) has eligible deposits above £85,000 because of more than one of the relevant life events, a claim may be made for compensation for both events and the protection limit applies separately to each event, meaning you assess the cap separately by event rather than pooling them into a single event [#SRC:9452d37938f9afef]. If the temporary high balance is from a personal injury or incapacity payment, the “no limit” rule overrides the cap for that payment-related balance [#TGT:b5fbb2a524d9ce87].

question: When Institutions are required to disclose information on remuneration policy and practices for staff whose activities materially affect the institutions’ risk profile, how must they determine the scope of that disclosure by reference to the specified points, and what does that imply about which elements are included or excluded?
gold_answer: Institutions must make remuneration disclosures specifically for those categories of staff whose professional activities have a material impact on the risk profile of the institutions, and the required disclosure is framed as an obligation to provide “the following information” about remuneration policy and practices for that staff population [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0]. The scope of what is to be disclosed is further bounded by the cross-reference that, “otherwise,” the relevant content is limited to points (a)–(d), (h)(i) and (h)(ii), which functions as a scoping instruction on which elements of the broader disclosure set are in play [#SRC:f5e543fdf42e5474]. Read together, this means Institutions should (i) identify the staff categories meeting the material-risk-impact condition and (ii) ensure that the disclosure content they provide for those staff categories aligns with the enumerated points referenced, rather than treating the obligation as open-ended. In practical terms, the disclosure duty applies to the defined staff scope and is satisfied by covering the specified points, with other potential items outside those points not being part of this “otherwise” scoped requirement.

question: What must Institutions disclose about pay policies for staff who can materially affect the institutions’ risk profile, and how do the listed points limit what needs to be covered?
gold_answer: Institutions have to disclose information about their remuneration policy and practices, but only for those categories of staff whose professional activities have a material impact on the risk profile of the institutions [#TGT:d3efeb25748ccfe0]. That obligation is not unlimited: the scope of what information is expected is constrained by the instruction that, “otherwise,” the relevant disclosure content is tied to points (a)–(d), (h)(i) and (h)(ii) [#SRC:f5e543fdf42e5474]. Putting these together, Institutions should first determine which staff categories meet the “material impact on risk profile” condition, because the disclosure duty is triggered for that group rather than for all staff. Then, for that staff group, Institutions should structure the disclosure so it covers the elements represented by the referenced points, treating those points as the defined set of items to address under this scoped approach. This combined reading clarifies both who the disclosure is about (the material-risk-impact staff categories) and what the disclosure must cover (the specified points), helping Institutions avoid under- or over-including information.

question: What does a firm have to put in place to keep a risk management system running day to day, and how should that system connect to risk tolerance limits and liquidity risk appetite and limits for UK Solvency II firms, the Society and managing agents?
gold_answer: A firm must have an effective risk-management system that it establishes, implements, and maintains, built from strategies, processes, and reporting procedures that work continuously to identify, measure, monitor, manage, and report risks the firm is or could be exposed to, both individually and in aggregate, including how those risks interact with each other [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca]. For UK Solvency II firms, the Society and managing agents, the system must also be implemented and maintained in a way that includes approved risk tolerance limits that put the insurer’s risk strategy into practice and support control mechanisms [#SRC:6ed49c6d770ad510]. In the liquidity area specifically, the source indicates that senior management should ensure there is a clearly defined liquidity risk appetite statement, identify material sources of liquidity risk, and set prudent limits for those sources, so liquidity risk is governed through explicit appetite and limits within the broader system [#SRC:6ed49c6d770ad510]. Taken together, the system should continuously produce the information and reporting needed to manage risks while also enforcing the firm’s chosen tolerances and liquidity limits as part of its overall risk strategy [#TGT:9f2e6ec1c2bc29ca].

question: From year-end 2025 onward, what must a firm submit to the PRA each year regarding its annual AoC exercise, and what separate submission must the firm make after it concludes its ORSA, including the applicable timing requirement?
gold_answer: Commencing year-end 2025, firms are required to provide the PRA with the results of their annual AoC exercise together with supporting narrative documentation on an annual basis, and the PRA also encourages earlier submission where possible to facilitate early engagement [#SRC:9003a68c0b5e882c]. Separately, once a firm has concluded its ORSA, it has a distinct obligation to submit the ORSA report, and it must do so within 10 business days after concluding the ORSA [#TGT:348990bd4143c14e]. Read together, these obligations mean a firm should plan for two different but potentially related reporting streams: (i) an annual AoC package (results plus supporting narrative documentation) submitted to the PRA each year from the specified commencement point, and (ii) an ORSA report submitted promptly after the ORSA is completed, subject to the 10-business-day deadline. The PRA’s encouragement of earlier AoC submission does not alter the ORSA timing requirement, which is framed as a mandatory post-conclusion deadline [#SRC:9003a68c0b5e882c] [#TGT:348990bd4143c14e].

question: When a firm is seeking new internal model permissions or a variation to existing permissions, what AoC-related materials may it be expected to submit to the PRA on the permission application date, and what additional report must it submit after concluding its ORSA and by when?
gold_answer: Where a firm seeks new internal model permissions or variations to existing permissions, it may be expected to submit to the PRA the results of an AoC exercise along with supporting narrative documentation, and it is expected to do so on the permission application date [#SRC:9003a68c0b5e882c]. This permission-linked expectation sits alongside the firm’s separate obligation relating to its ORSA process: after the firm concludes its ORSA, it must submit the ORSA report within 10 business days following that conclusion [#TGT:348990bd4143c14e]. In practice, the firm should treat the AoC submission tied to the permission application date as a point-in-time deliverable that may be triggered by the permissions process, while the ORSA report submission is triggered by completion of the ORSA and is governed by a fixed post-event deadline. The two requirements can therefore operate on different timelines (application date versus ORSA conclusion), and both must be met when applicable, with the AoC materials focused on AoC results and narrative support and the ORSA obligation focused on timely delivery of the ORSA report [#SRC:9003a68c0b5e882c] [#TGT:348990bd4143c14e].

question: When the PRA states that a statement was subject to public consultation and reflects feedback received, what specific consultation paper should be treated as the referenced consultation, and how should that identification be documented for audit purposes?
gold_answer: Where the PRA indicates that a statement has been subject to public consultation and reflects feedback received by the PRA, the consultation should be identified by reference to the specific consultation paper cited in the related materials. In this case, the consultation referenced is PRA Consultation Paper CP16/14, titled ‘Transposition of Solvency II: Part 3’. The compliance record should therefore link the statement’s consultation and feedback basis to PRA Consultation Paper CP16/14 as the concrete consultation source, noting that the statement’s content is described as reflecting the feedback received by the PRA through that public consultation process. This approach aligns the general assertion of consultation and feedback incorporation in the statement [#SRC:0a7338a958d258c0] with the explicit identification of the consultation paper and its title in the cross-referenced citation [#TGT:4ee0ec115e0fbd36]. For completeness, documentation may also retain the consultation paper’s publicly available reference location (as provided alongside the citation) to evidence traceability between the statement, the public consultation, and the feedback channel described by the PRA.

question: The PRA says a statement went through public consultation and reflects feedback it received. Which named consultation paper is that referring to, and what should you write down to show the link?
gold_answer: If the PRA explains that a statement was subject to public consultation and that it reflects the feedback received by the PRA, you should connect that general description to the specific consultation paper that is cited for the consultation. Here, the named consultation is PRA Consultation Paper CP16/14, ‘Transposition of Solvency II: Part 3’. In your notes or compliance file, record that the statement’s public consultation and feedback basis (as described by the PRA) is tied to PRA Consultation Paper CP16/14, and that the statement is presented as reflecting feedback received by the PRA through that consultation. This directly links the statement’s consultation-and-feedback claim [#SRC:0a7338a958d258c0] to the concrete consultation paper identifier and title provided in the citation [#TGT:4ee0ec115e0fbd36]. To make the link easy to evidence later, keep the consultation paper reference details together with the statement record so reviewers can trace from the statement to the consultation paper.

question: Under the General Governance Requirements, what does a firm have to do to make sure its governing body is finally accountable for compliance, and which rules and firms does this cover?
gold_answer: Under the General Governance Requirements, a firm must set up its governance so that the governing body is the place where ultimate responsibility for compliance sits. This is not just about day-to-day compliance tasks; the firm must ensure the governing body remains finally accountable for whether the firm complies. The compliance scope covered by that ultimate responsibility includes the PRA rules and FSMA, and it also includes all applicable laws, rules, regulations, and administrative provisions that derive from FSMA and apply in the relevant circumstances. The obligation is stated as applying to UK Solvency II firms, so the firm should treat that as the key applicability condition when deciding whether and how the requirement applies to it. Put simply, if the firm is a UK Solvency II firm, it must ensure its governing body is ultimately responsible for compliance across the PRA and FSMA framework and the applicable FSMA-derived provisions, consistent with the General Governance Requirements scope [#SRC:0938859486aaa007] and the specific governing body accountability obligation [#TGT:3f2bf01fcca95c14].

question: If a PRA-authorised bank or designated investment firm is a ‘UK trading bank’ (UK-headquartered or in a UK-based group, with investment banking or sales and trading in the UK and overseas), what does it need to do about who oversees booking arrangements and how that is written down, and what should it consider for people in the parent or group entities who strongly influence its UK regulated activities?
gold_answer: If the firm is within the scope described for ‘UK trading banks’—a PRA-authorised bank or designated investment firm that is headquartered in the UK or part of a group based in the UK and that has investment banking or sales and trading activities in both the UK and overseas—then the PRA’s booking-arrangements expectations apply to it as set out, including the stated clarification of when expectations apply to international banks alone versus international banks and UK trading banks [#SRC:a3ab5e4ef313b90a]. Where those expectations are applicable, the PRA expects the firm to assign responsibility for overseeing the firm’s booking arrangements to an SMF and to record that responsibility appropriately in the firm’s Statement of Responsibilities, so there is clear documented accountability [#TGT:a696590f07b39032]. The firm should also look beyond its own legal entity: where individuals in the parent or in group entities have significant influence over the management or conduct of one or more aspects of the firm’s UK regulated activities, it may be appropriate for the firm to have those individuals approved as a Group Entity Senior Manager (SMF7), noting that firms have applied for SMF7 approval for individuals performing a range of functions [#TGT:a696590f07b39032].

question: If a firm pairs or groups assets, what does it need to be able to explain about how it treated that pairing/grouping in matching and in the MA calculation, including whether it de-risked and mapped each element to FSs separately or treated the combined asset as one?
gold_answer: When a firm uses pairing or grouping arrangements for assets, it needs to be able to explain its treatment of those arrangements and also be able to justify the method it used in both the assessment of matching and the calculation of the MA. That means the firm should not only describe what it did, but show that it considered carefully how the pairing or grouping was reflected in the matching assessment and MA calculation. A key part of this explanation is being clear about the level at which de-risking and mapping to FSs was performed. The firm should be able to explain whether it de-risked and mapped all the individual elements of the arrangement separately to FSs, or whether it instead treated the arrangement as a combined asset, de-risked that combined asset, and mapped it onto a single FS. This is required because, where assets are grouped or paired, firms should be able to explain their approach [#SRC:230e4a56470a2af1], and the PRA expects firms to be able to justify the method used for reflecting pairing/grouping in matching and MA [#TGT:3b17ff239c842f77].

question: If a firm uses a third party to run investment-related activities, what must the firm still be responsible for, and what limits still apply to the assets it may invest in based on its ability to understand and manage the risks?
gold_answer: If a firm outsources investment-related activities, it must still treat itself as accountable for meeting its regulatory obligations: outsourcing does not remove the firm’s responsibility for discharging all of its obligations under the PRA rules and FSMA-derived requirements that apply to UK Solvency II firms [#TGT:9bd0b34f08f21d51]. At the same time, the firm may only invest in assets where it can identify, measure, monitor, manage, control, and report the risks, and where it can take those risks into account in its assessment of own solvency needs as part of the ORSA [#SRC:cefa040f166b123d]. This means the firm must set up its outsourcing and oversight so it can still obtain the information and maintain the controls needed to understand and manage investment risks, rather than relying on the provider alone. The firm’s risk management framework should support this outcome by enabling the firm to keep effective risk monitoring, management, and reporting, and to ensure investment risks are properly reflected in solvency needs even when investment activities are outsourced [#SRC:cefa040f166b123d] [#TGT:9bd0b34f08f21d51].

question: For a UK ISPV, how should the term “prescribed responsibility” be understood for purposes of the requirement to allocate responsibilities, and to whom must those responsibilities be allocated?
gold_answer: A “prescribed responsibility” is any responsibility that is identified as such by the rule itself—i.e., every responsibility that the rule lists is, by definition, a prescribed responsibility [#TGT:ffb5ca3e5483ef39]. Applying that definition to the allocation obligation, a UK ISPV must treat each responsibility referenced in the allocation requirement as falling within the prescribed-responsibility category and must ensure none are omitted. The UK ISPV is required to allocate each of those prescribed responsibilities to one or more persons, and the persons selected must be individuals who, in relation to that firm, are approved under section 59 of FSMA by the relevant approving authority referenced in the obligation [#SRC:e25d8ddb7e1c5f0f]. In practice, this means the firm’s compliance approach should (i) identify the responsibilities the rule sets out, (ii) confirm they are “prescribed responsibilities” under the definition, and (iii) document an allocation of each such responsibility to at least one appropriately approved person, allowing allocation to more than one person where the firm chooses to do so, provided the approval condition is met [#SRC:e25d8ddb7e1c5f0f] [#TGT:ffb5ca3e5483ef39].

question: Which PRA document should you point to when explaining how reporting and disclosure requirements and regulatory transactions forms are interpreted after EU withdrawal, and what date should you note for that document in your compliance log?
gold_answer: You should point to the PRA’s Supervisory Statement (SS) 2/19, which is described as covering the PRA approach to interpreting reporting and disclosure requirements and regulatory transactions forms after EU withdrawal [#SRC:1f68bebfece14e5e]. When you log or cite it internally, you should also note the date shown alongside the SS2/19 entry in the related listing, which is “December 2020,” and which is tied to the same topic—PRA approach to interpreting reporting and disclosure requirements and regulatory transactions forms after the UK’s withdrawal from the EU [#TGT:09c0152364d86685]. Using both pieces together makes your record clearer: the SOURCE confirms the exact document type and title framing (a Supervisory Statement, SS 2/19), while the TARGET provides the specific date (December 2020) associated with SS2/19 in that listing. This helps ensure your explanation and documentation consistently identify the correct PRA material and its recorded timing.

question: When an undertaking is required to comply with the own-funds requirements referenced in the source provision, what must it ensure about the selection of the features referred to in 3D, and how must those features align with the specified 3E options?
gold_answer: An undertaking that is subject to the own-funds compliance obligation must ensure two things operate together. First, it must comply with the requirements set out across the referenced own-funds framework, including the requirements identified in the source provision as applicable to the undertaking [#SRC:a921eba68eebf990]. Second, where the regime refers to “features” in 3D, the undertaking must ensure that any such features are not chosen arbitrarily but instead fall within the permitted set: they must be either the features set out in 3E.1(1) to (10) or the features set out in 3E.1(11) [#TGT:431206cfdfe5d688]. Read together, this means the undertaking’s compliance is not only about meeting the broader own-funds requirements, but also about ensuring that any 3D-referenced features it relies on are drawn exclusively from the specified 3E alternatives. In practice, the undertaking should verify that the features it identifies for the relevant purpose correspond to one of the two 3E groupings, and then ensure its overall own-funds position remains compliant with the referenced requirements.

question: Given that the board must state whether there have been any material changes to the financial position between the period covered by the financial information and approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, how will the PRA proceed in determining whether the relevant criterion is met, and how will any failure to disclose such interim changes factor into that determination?
gold_answer: Because the financial information necessarily relates to a period ending before approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, the board must make an explicit statement on whether any material changes to the financial position have occurred in the interim, and if a change cannot be quantified it must still be described so members understand it has been identified and is relevant to their consideration of the proposed merger [#SRC:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. The PRA’s procedure for assessing the related criterion is framed as an “approach to determining whether this criterion is met,” meaning the PRA will apply an evaluative process directed at that criterion rather than treating it as a purely formal check [#TGT:e58b7126c991215d]. In applying that approach, the PRA’s subsequent consideration of the society’s application for confirmation of the merger will treat any failure to disclose such interim material changes as relevant, so omissions in the board’s statement (or missing descriptions where quantification is not possible) can affect how the PRA assesses whether the criterion has been satisfied in the context of the confirmation application [#SRC:ee19b3e79f8edaa1] [#TGT:e58b7126c991215d].

question: When the board has to say whether there were any important financial changes after the period covered by the financial information but before approval of the Schedule 16 Statement, what is the PRA’s process for deciding if the criterion is met, and what happens if those changes are not disclosed?
gold_answer: The board’s required step is to state whether or not there have been any material changes to the financial position in the period between the end date covered by the financial information and the date the Schedule 16 Statement is approved; where the effect of a change cannot be quantified, the board must still describe it so members know it has been identified and is relevant to their consideration of the proposed merger [#SRC:ee19b3e79f8edaa1]. The PRA then applies its stated approach to determining whether the relevant criterion is met, i.e., it uses an assessment process aimed at deciding whether that criterion has been satisfied rather than assuming it is met automatically [#TGT:e58b7126c991215d]. In that assessment, the PRA’s later consideration of the society’s application for confirmation of the merger will treat a failure to disclose interim material changes as relevant, so missing statements about changes (or missing descriptions when quantification is not possible) can weigh against the society when the PRA evaluates the confirmation application under its approach [#SRC:ee19b3e79f8edaa1] [#TGT:e58b7126c991215d].

question: When Institutions are required to make disclosures on exposures to securitisation positions, how must they structure those disclosures if they calculate risk-weighted exposure amounts under the securitisation framework or determine own funds requirements for trading book exposures? In particular, must the information be presented separately for trading and non-trading book activities, and what triggers that separation requirement?
gold_answer: Institutions must make disclosures on their exposures to securitisation positions in the manner required for those disclosures, and the obligation is engaged specifically for Institutions that are calculating risk-weighted exposure amounts under the securitisation approach or that are calculating own funds requirements under the relevant trading book provisions. In practice, this means the securitisation-exposure disclosures obligation applies to Institutions as such [#SRC:0df0797a9877c085], and, where the Institution falls within the scope of calculating risk-weighted exposure amounts in accordance with the securitisation chapter or own funds requirements in accordance with the specified trading book articles, it must disclose the required information separately for its trading and non-trading book activities [#TGT:c436a14243ca6883]. The separation is therefore not an optional presentation choice: it is a required structuring of the disclosed information that is triggered by the Institution’s use of those calculation frameworks. Accordingly, an Institution should ensure that its securitisation-position exposure disclosures are organised so that trading book and non-trading book activities are clearly distinguished whenever it is performing those calculations, to align the securitisation disclosure obligation with the required trading/non-trading split.

question: If Institutions have to disclose their exposures to securitisation positions, do they also have to split the disclosed information between trading book and non-trading book activities when they calculate risk-weighted exposure amounts or own funds requirements under the specified methods?
gold_answer: Institutions must make the required disclosures about their exposures to securitisation positions [#SRC:0df0797a9877c085]. Where an Institution is in the category that calculates risk-weighted exposure amounts under the securitisation framework or calculates own funds requirements under the specified provisions, it must disclose the relevant information separately for its trading and non-trading book activities [#TGT:c436a14243ca6883]. Put simply, the obligation to disclose securitisation-position exposures applies to Institutions, and the way the information must be presented depends on whether the Institution is performing those particular calculations. If it is, the disclosure cannot be a single combined presentation across all activities; it must be split so that trading book activities and non-trading book activities are shown separately. This means an Institution should prepare its securitisation exposure disclosures in a format that clearly distinguishes between the two books whenever it is calculating risk-weighted exposure amounts in the securitisation chapter or own funds requirements under the specified articles, so the disclosures both cover securitisation positions and meet the required separation by activity.

question: When preparing a recovery plan that must cover a range of severe macroeconomic and financial stress scenarios relevant to the firm’s specific conditions, how must TWD firms use sensitivity analysis to quantify the impact of alternative key assumptions and communicate the plausible range of impacts on capital and liquidity projections following execution of the TWD option?
gold_answer: A recovery plan must contemplate a range of scenarios of severe macroeconomic and financial stress that are relevant to the firm’s specific conditions, including system-wide events and stress specific to individual legal persons and to groups [#TGT:b05c0e996e2dafa2]. In that context, TWD firms should also be able to conduct sensitivity analysis to quantify the impact of alternative key assumptions to those assumed under the TWD scenario [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f]. TWD firms should use these sensitivity analysis capabilities to set out upper and lower bounds for their key assumptions so that senior management can understand the range of plausible impacts on the firm’s capital and liquidity projections following execution of the TWD option [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f]. The sensitivity analysis capability should include an ability to analyse the minimum baseline set of factors included as part of the TWD scenario, among other factors, so that the recovery plan’s scenario range is supported by quantified impacts and bounded assumptions aligned to the firm’s conditions and stress scenarios [#SRC:b6ce98b0d799fd2f; #TGT:b05c0e996e2dafa2].

question: If a firm decides it does not have to follow some requirements because they are not proportionate for its business and activities, what must it still do to make sure the compliance function can work properly and independently?
gold_answer: A firm can be allowed not to comply with certain requirements if, looking at the nature, scale and complexity of its business and the nature and range of the relevant services and activities, complying would not be proportionate, and if the firm’s compliance function is, and continues to be, effective [#SRC:029ad42316e71977]. But that flexibility does not remove the firm’s duty to support the compliance function’s role. The firm must still ensure that the compliance function is able to discharge its responsibilities properly and independently [#TGT:56dd025c30f9e7e2]. Putting both points together, the firm should only rely on the “not proportionate” basis where it can maintain an effective compliance function over time, and it must also keep conditions in place that allow the compliance function to carry out its responsibilities properly and without undue influence. In practice, the firm needs to make a reasoned proportionality judgment based on its business and activities, while ensuring the compliance function remains effective and can operate properly and independently [#SRC:029ad42316e71977] [#TGT:56dd025c30f9e7e2].

question: When Institutions calculate risk-weighted exposure amounts under the IRB Approach to credit risk, what must they do to ensure the required IRB-related information is both disclosed and published in the prescribed manner?
gold_answer: Where Institutions calculate the risk-weighted exposure amounts under the IRB Approach to credit risk, they have a disclosure obligation specific to that IRB calculation context: they must disclose the information that is required for Institutions using that approach. In addition, Institutions must not treat that disclosure as an informal communication; they must publish the disclosures that are required under Titles II and III, and they must do so in the manner specified for those publications. Read together, this means Institutions should (i) identify the IRB-related information that must be disclosed when they calculate risk-weighted exposure amounts under the IRB Approach to credit risk, and (ii) ensure that this disclosure is delivered through the publication process and format that applies to required disclosures under Titles II and III, rather than through an ad hoc channel. The combined effect is that IRB-related disclosures are both made (disclosed) and made available through the required publication mechanism (published in the prescribed manner), aligning the content trigger in the IRB context with the broader publication requirement. [#TGT:583597bc789f85c7] [#SRC:a2135b9576433803]

question: Do Institutions have to do anything beyond disclosing IRB-related information when they calculate risk-weighted exposure amounts under the IRB Approach to credit risk?
gold_answer: Yes. When Institutions calculate the risk-weighted exposure amounts under the IRB Approach to credit risk, they must disclose the information required for that IRB context. But they also have an additional, related duty about how required disclosures are made available: Institutions must publish the disclosures required under Titles II and III, and they must publish them in the manner set out for those disclosures. So, Institutions should not stop at preparing the IRB disclosure content; they should also ensure that the disclosure is handled through the required publication process that applies to Titles II and III disclosures. This means the IRB disclosure requirement drives the need to disclose specific information in the IRB calculation scenario, while the publication obligation ensures that required disclosures (including those that are required in that scenario) are formally published and presented in the prescribed manner. Together, these obligations require both disclosure and compliant publication. [#TGT:583597bc789f85c7] [#SRC:a2135b9576433803]

question: For groups within the scope of this Part at group level, how should the requirements that are triggered when the relevant condition applies be implemented for an insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company without its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, or for a third country insurance undertaking or third country reinsurance undertaking, including the expectation that they are applied with necessary modifications and any stated limitation?
gold_answer: The TARGET establishes that the regulatory framework in question is intended to operate “at the level of the group” and is directed to specified “types of groups” that fall within the Part’s scope [#TGT:68c8c37fed32deed]. Within that group-level framing, the SOURCE explains how certain requirements are to be carried across when the relevant condition is met: specified provisions (including External Audit requirements) are to be applied “with any necessary changes” at the level of particular non-UK/non-Gibraltar or third-country entities. The entities expressly covered by this adaptation mechanism are an insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company that does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, as well as a third country insurance undertaking and a third country reinsurance undertaking [#SRC:4b76a4f92f32f4d8]. Read together, the scope point is that, for in-scope group types under the Part, the compliance approach is not limited to the group in the abstract; it requires implementing the referenced requirements at the level of those specified holding-company or third-country undertaking entities, adjusted as needed to fit that level. The SOURCE also signals a limitation by introducing an “unless” carve-out, indicating that the application is subject to an exception condition [#SRC:4b76a4f92f32f4d8].

question: This Part applies to certain types of groups at group level. When the trigger condition is met, what does it mean in practice to apply the listed requirements (including External Audit) with necessary changes at the level of an insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company outside the UK or Gibraltar, or at the level of a third country insurance or reinsurance undertaking, and is there any carve-out?
gold_answer: The TARGET sets the boundary that the rules in this Part are meant to apply “at the level of the group” and only for the “types of groups” that fall within its scope [#TGT:68c8c37fed32deed]. The SOURCE then explains what happens once the relevant trigger condition applies: a set of specified requirements, including External Audit requirements, must be carried over and implemented “with any necessary changes” at the level of certain entities rather than only being considered at a high, consolidated group description. The entities named are an insurance holding company or mixed financial holding company that does not have its head office in the UK or Gibraltar, and also a third country insurance undertaking or a third country reinsurance undertaking [#SRC:4b76a4f92f32f4d8]. Putting both passages together, if a group is within the Part’s group-level scope, and the trigger condition is met, the compliance expectation is to apply those requirements in an adapted way at the level of those specific non-UK/non-Gibraltar or third-country entities. The SOURCE also indicates there is an exception by stating the application applies “unless” a further condition is met, so the obligation is not absolute in every case [#SRC:4b76a4f92f32f4d8].

question: When the firm works out its exposure to each type of asset by adjusting the asset value, what must it do if it has already transferred assets of that same type as initial margin—does it have to add an extra amount to the value first?
gold_answer: The firm must assign a value to assets of each description using the applicable valuation approach, and then determine how much it is exposed to those assets by adjusting that value under the relevant adjustment method [#TGT:596695fe437c2dff]. If the firm has transferred assets of a particular description by way of initial margin, it must not ignore those transferred assets when setting the value for that description. Instead, the value ascribed for that description must be increased by an amount that represents the value of the assets of that description that have been transferred as initial margin [#SRC:b5aade12a934b433]. Putting both requirements together: before the firm finalizes the adjusted value used to determine exposure for a given asset description, it must include an uplift that captures the value of any same-description assets it has already transferred as initial margin. This ensures the exposure calculation is based on an ascribed value that has been appropriately increased to reflect the transferred initial margin assets, and then adjusted as required for exposure determination.

question: When a firm designs and maintains its contingency and business continuity arrangements, what must it do to ensure ongoing operability and loss limitation during severe disruption, and how must those arrangements reflect the expectation that business continuity plans take relevant considerations into account?
gold_answer: A firm must put in place a complete business continuity framework that is not merely documented but also established, implemented, and maintained as an operational capability, so that the firm can continue operating on an ongoing basis and limit losses if a severe business disruption occurs [#TGT:a9660219bd658d5f]. In doing so, the firm’s business continuity plans must be developed in a way that takes into account the relevant considerations that the applicable organisational requirements expect firms to consider when preparing such plans [#SRC:9fd5b146e366875d]. Read together, this means the firm should treat the “take into account” expectation as shaping the content and design of the plans, while the obligation to establish, implement, and maintain them sets the required lifecycle and outcome focus: operational resilience, continuity of service, and loss limitation under severe disruption. The firm should therefore ensure its plans are sufficiently robust and current to support ongoing operation, and that the planning process explicitly incorporates the considerations that the organisational requirements indicate should be reflected in business continuity planning [#SRC:9fd5b146e366875d] alongside the contingency and continuity objective in the disruption scenario [#TGT:a9660219bd658d5f].

question: What does a firm have to do about contingency and business continuity plans so it can keep operating and reduce losses during a major disruption, and how should those plans reflect the requirement that business continuity planning takes certain considerations into account?
gold_answer: A firm must have contingency and business continuity plans that are actually put into practice and kept up to date: it must establish them, implement them, and maintain them so the firm can continue operating on an ongoing basis and limit losses if there is a severe business disruption [#TGT:a9660219bd658d5f]. At the same time, the firm’s business continuity plans are expected to be prepared in a way that takes into account the relevant considerations identified by the applicable organisational requirements for business continuity planning [#SRC:9fd5b146e366875d]. Together, these points mean the firm cannot treat business continuity planning as a one-off document exercise. The plans must be designed with the required disruption outcomes in mind (continued operation and loss limitation) and must also be built using the “take into account” expectation as a guide for what the plans should cover and reflect [#SRC:9fd5b146e366875d]. In practice, the firm should ensure its planning approach explicitly incorporates those considerations while maintaining plans that remain effective for ongoing operations during severe disruption [#TGT:a9660219bd658d5f].

question: Where more than one SMF holds the prescribed responsibility for the production and integrity of the firm’s financial information and its regulatory reporting (PR Q), how should the firm determine who must provide the attestation, and how does the supervisory guidance publication identified in June 2021 support the PRA’s expectation on shared prescribed responsibilities?
gold_answer: If more than one SMF holds PR Q, the PRA’s expectation is that all of those SMFs must provide the attestation, rather than selecting only one individual, because the relevant SMF(s) should have ultimate governance responsibility for the calculation of the FS and MA regardless of any delegation and therefore be able to implement an increase to the FS if required [#SRC:60350a1cc8a674eb]. In practice, the attesting SMF will often be SMF 2 (the Chief Financial Officer), but the appropriate SMF could be another SMF depending on how responsibility is allocated within the firm; if the firm’s governance arrangements indicate an alternative SMF would be more appropriate, the firm should approach its usual supervisory contact in the first instance [#SRC:60350a1cc8a674eb]. This expectation is reinforced by the PRA’s view that the supervisory guidance on sharing prescribed responsibilities in SS35/15 – Strengthening individual accountability in insurance applies, and that guidance is the publication referenced as “June 2021” at the Bank of England link provided [#TGT:b14f188f94d343a7].

question: If a firm has more than one SMF with PR Q, who is expected to sign the attestation, and what does the June 2021 link to SS35/15 tell you about how the PRA treats shared prescribed responsibilities?
gold_answer: When more than one SMF holds PR Q (the prescribed responsibility for the production and integrity of the firm’s financial information and its regulatory reporting), the PRA expects all of those SMFs to attest, not just one of them [#SRC:60350a1cc8a674eb]. The reason given is that the relevant SMF should have ultimate governance responsibility for the calculation of the FS and MA regardless of delegations, and therefore be in a position to implement an increase to the FS if required [#SRC:60350a1cc8a674eb].
